div.head: A REPLY TO THE ANSWERER OF THE LETTER Sent to the AUTHOR of a PAPER, CALLED The Doctrine of Passive Obedience and Jure Divino disproved.
div.p:
THE Preface to the Objections sent against your half sheet, your pleas'd to call an unnecessary Prologue, which therefore you have thought fit wholly to omit. I am willing to give you as little trouble as may be, and shall not spend time in proving either the necessity or pertinency of it. Whether it was properly accommodated to your Person you know best, and with your Conscience I leave it. However if I was mistaken in my suspicions concerning you, you resolve, it
seems, to be even with me; when, without mincing the matter, you call me notorious hypocrite: And that for no other Reason, but for Preaching up Passive Obedience to others, and yet at the same time, assuring you, that I am and shall be, as averse from having my throat cut as you are. p. 3, 6. of your Answer.

For, Pray Sir, consider again, cannot I be for the Passive Doctrine, but I must be willing to have my throat cut? And if I be not willing to have my throat cut, must I need be for resisting any Man or Men whatsoever, who shall endeavour to take away my life contrary to Law? What connexion is there betwixt these things? Or does there need an Oedipus to reconcile these contrarieties (as you call them)? May I not love my life so well, as to be unwilling to have my • hroat cut? And yet may I not at the same time, have such a re • ard to my Duty, as to be willing to part with my life rather then loose it Eternally, by ranking my self amongst the number of those, who by resistance, shall receive to themselves damnation? Upon second thoughts, it's probable, you may think your self too blame for passing such a rash censure upon me. However, I'm well assured, that no sober Man and good Christian, will judge me worthy of the Character of notorious hypocrite, meerly because I am willing to preserve my Life, as a Man endued with natural Inclinations, when yet I am ready to lay it down, rather then save it by such practises, as I judge repugnant to my Duty as a Christian, oblig'd by the Laws of Christianity.

In Truth, Sir, to deal plainly with you, your Reasonings in the Judgment of some of your Friends as well as my self, have so little weight and moment in them, that I am likely to make but very small Improvement of my time, by undertaking to examin and refute them. Abating some of your hard Words (such as inhuman and damnable Principles p. 37.) you bring nothing that would affrighten a well Educated School Boy (who, out of his Catechism, has been instructed in his Duty to God and the King) from undertaking you. I confess, by your half sheet, I guess'd that I had ingaged with a
Master in the Cause; and was afraid that your streng • h of Reason, and dextrous Management might have caused me to have repented of my rashness, and have at least exposed me as an incompetent Defendor of Passive Obedience, tho' in it self, it be never so capable of being defended.

But I perceive, it is not always true, that second thoughts are the best and wisest; and that some Persons, to the end that their Readers may believe more then they can prove, boldly venture to promise more then they can perform. And whether or no you have made use of this Artifice (so common with all great undertakers) I leave it to any one to determin; who will take the pains to compare the several Propositions of your Title-page, with what you have said in the Body of your Book to prove them. He must be one of the meanest capacity indeed, who can perswade himself that you have made good your Title-page Propositions; unless it be to the meanest capacity in this sense.

You have (you say) set down my Answer Verbatim, that the Readers may better judge of the ridiculousness thereof. What the Readers will judge of my Answer, I know not; however I am oblig'd to you for your kindness. Pardon me, Sir, if in requital I do not set down your Reply Verbatim; for this would be to Ridicule the Reader as well as to render the Reply it self ridiculous. I shall therefore only desire the Reader (of what perswasion soever, if intelligent) first to consider what you promise in the Title-page, and then examin whether you have substantially proved any one (much less every one) of those specious Propositions, with which you flatter the People? And if none of those nine rare things, which you promise to shew, shall appear to him after he has perused all your Paragraphs, he'l be apt, I believe, to judge you ridiculous, or something worse. They must either want wit or honesty, who propose mighty matters, when they perform little, or nothing at all. Yet such Quacks there are, and always will be in the World; and whether you be not sufficiently qualify'd to set up for one of them, I shall leave those to judge, who have
so much time to throw away, as to take a view of your wonderful curiosities.

But 'tis time to come to particulars. And here, because we seem to be agreed about the number of Breaks or Sentences, in the first Paper, I shall observe the same Method in my Remarks upon your Reply, which you have; in your Observations upon my short Return, to your couragious Challenge to all the poor Passive Obedience and Jure Divino Men in all England, nay in the whole World. And I intreat no other favour of those, who shall think it worth their while to judge betwixt us, but that they will first read over every one of the Breaks or Sentences in the first Paper (which gave occasion to this dispute) and then consider my Answer thereunto; before they proceed to the Author's Animadversions thereupon; which when they have impartially examin'd, I desire, in the last place, that they will read over this Rejoynder; and then, without Favour or Affection, judge whether of us two hath Right on his side; and hath done most Justice to the Principles of Reason and Religion, the Laws and Church of England.

(N. 1.) To begin. In your first Paper, your first Proposition is, that God by no Word Binds any People to this or that Form of Government, till they, by their own Act, Bind themselves. To this I Answered, —That Monarchy is the Government which God hath chosen above all others; and that the People, were always obliged to accept of that Form of Government which God had chosen for them, before they did actually Bind themselves. SEE HIM (said Samuel to all the People) WHOM THE LORD (not you) HATH CHOSEN. 1 Sam. x. 24. Now what is your Reply? Why you quote a great many Texts of Scripture, and when you have done, make your own Remarks upon them, and then think you have effectually answer'd me. For example, because the Text says.—He told the People the manner of the Kingdom, and wrote it in a Book, and laid it up before the Lord, 1 Sam. x. 25. you argue thus.—Surely no Man will say, but that this Law was a Rule for the King to go by as well as the People. And then, where (you ask) was his Absolute Authority? In which Argument you
insinuate, as if I denyed that the Law, or Manner of the Ki • gdom was a Law to the King as well as the People. Which I am so far from maintaining, that on the contrary, I do say, that the King as well as his People is obliged in Conscience and in the sight of God to observe the Law, as far as it concerns him. Saul when he broke the Law, which God had made the measure of his Power, was in the Court of Heaven no more excusable, than one of his meanest Subjects. Yet his Subjects had no Warrant to call him to an account for what he had done. So that his Authority, in this respect, was not at all diminished by the Law or Manner of the King. And thus you have an Answer to your Question, where then was his Absolute Authority? And indeed you do unluckily Appeal to this Law, or Manner of the Kingdom, which Samuel wrote in a Book, &c. For the Right or Prerogative of the King is therein so described, that it gives him an Absolute Authority indeed, over the People, whilst it leaves to them little else but the Obligation and Duty of Obedience. Such a Law or Manner of the King as this was, you would I believe, be very loath to have entered into our Law-Books, and inserted into the Magna Charta of England.

But because the People did solemnly own, recognise, and (as you express it) confirm their Kings, this (say you with particular respect to Solomon's Case) makes not a little for the Peoples Right in electing their Kings. In truth this makes just nothing at all for the People's Right in electing their Kings. For how, I beseech you, doth it appear, that the People, have any Right to elect, when they are only to approve and receive him, whom God before hath chosen for them; as in the Examples of Saul and Solomon, to which you refer; i Sam. xi. 14, 15. i Chron. xxix. 22? As for what I said concerning Jeroboam, you grant that he was elected by the People; but withal (you say) that he was King by the appointment of Almighty God. And so indeed he was, as War, Pestilence and Famine are by the appointment of Almighty God but no otherwise; notwithstanding that Text, which you cite for this purpose very fallaciously. But so it often happens, that they
who accuse others wrongfully, are themselves suffer'd to fall into that Guilt which they charge upon their innocent Neighbour. You ask me with what face I can wrest the Scriptures thus, in saying that the People's chusing Jeroboam, is more then once called a Sin (Rebellion) when both these Texts, which you quote, relates to the foregoing Verses, wherein 'tis said, that King Rehoboam sent Adoram, that was over the Tribute; and all Israel stoned him with Stones, that he dyed? which (Act of the People) was (you say) Rebellion, because it was resisting the lawful Authority; besides Jeroboam is not mentioned as King, till after this Act was Committed. This is the charge (with the Reasons thereof) which you exhibit against me. I shall now clear my self, and then shew, that the Fault you accuse me of, you have really made your own by misapplication of Scripture to your present purpose, either through Ignorance, or (which is worse) evil Design.

As to the first I say again, that those Places, 1 Kings xii. 19. and ii Chron. x. 19. do relate to the Rebellion of the Ten Tribes in falling off from Rehoboam their lawful King, to Jeroboam the Usurper. For, as soon as they had heard Rehoboam's Answer, which was according to the Counsel of the young Men, v. 14. they presently began to be Seditious, gave the Signal of War, and were resolv'd to have a King of their own making, and to cast him off, who was the rightful Heir of the House of David. The People answered the King, saying, what Portion have we in David? neither have Inheritance in the Son of Jesse. To your Tents, O Israel, now see to thine House, David, v. 16. After they had thus bidden open Defiance to King Rehoboam, and were departed to their Tents fully purposed to carry on their Rebellious Enterprise, Rehoboam (hoping to appease and reduce them to Obedience) sent Adoram to them, but they were so far from hearkning to him, or any Conditions which he had to propose to them, from the King, that they presently stoned him with Stones, that he dyed; and if Rehoboam had not with all speed fled
in his Chariot to Jerusalem, they would in all likelihood, have seized his Person, and used him as they should have thought fit, v. 18. All this they did under the Conduct of Jeroboam, who headed them at the first, when they went to Petition Rehoboam, v. 3. without doubt therefore they had him in their Eyes from the beginning of their Defection. And so it may be truly said that this Act of the People (i. e. Making Jeroboam King) is both in this place and ii Chron. x. 19.) called Rebellion. They resisted Adoram, because (as they supposed) he was sent to prevent their designs for Jeroboam; whom (as it follows in the next v.) they immediately, made King over all Israel. And now I appeal unto any one, who will impartially consider this History, as it is recorded in the places above mentioned, whether you have not unjustly accus'd me for wresting of the Scriptures, when I said, that these Illegal and Arbitrary Proceedings of the People in electing their New King, are in Scripture, mark't with the infamous Note of Rebellion?

Let me now ask you, How you can excuse your self from aequivocating, and wresting the Scriptures to your own private Sence, when, upon the Authority of the Prophet Ahijah's Words to Jeroboam,—Thus saith the Lord, I will take the Kingdom out of his Son's Hand (i. e. Rehoboam's, Solomon's Son) and give it unto thee, even Ten Tribes, i King. xi. 5, you affirm, That Rehoboam, was a King, by the appointment of Almighty God, though elected by the People? For what, I ask, do you mean by the appointment of Almighty God? That he permitted only this Defection, as a Punishment of Solomon's Sin? or that he did positively approve and order it, as much as he did that David should Succeed in the Throne, after the Death of King Saul? If the former; you ought plainly to have said so, that the unwary Reader might not be deceived by an ambiguous Expression. If the later; you must own and defend this false Principle, as grounded upon Scripture — That Ʋsurpers, and they who in an Hereditary Monarchy ascend the Throne by the People's Defection or Rebellion to their lawful
Prince, are as much by God's appointment, as they who possess the Crown by the Right of Hereditary Succession. God, who sees all things at once, foresaw the People's Sin; which for the Punishment of Solomon's Luxury and Idolatry, he suffer'd to come to that height as to ripen into a prosperous Rebellion against Rehoboam. This, God was pleas'd to reveal unto his Prophet, and order'd him to tell it unto Jeroboam, in these words—Thus saith the Lord, I will take, &c.— What is there in these words whence we can infer, that Jeroboam was a King by the appointment of Almighty God, any more than we can conclude, from Jeremiah's Prophesy, concerning the Captivity of Hezekiah and the City (Jer. xxxiv) that this Captivity was by the appointment of Almighty God? the King of Babylon was suffered to burn the City and lead Zedekiah Captive; but yet in all this, the King of Babylon was nevertheless a grievous Tyrant; whose Cruelty and Injustice, God did by no means approve, or positively appoint, but only order'd and determined his Wickedness so, as to serve the ends of his Providence, in punishing the Sins of his People.

(N. 2.) All the difference betwixt us in this Point is, that you will needs consider the greatness of the Sovereign, as accompanied with the publick Detriment; Whereas I am desirous to joyn the Sovereign Greatness and the Publick Benefit together, and make these two Friends and Companions to one another. No Sovereign can become really Great by striving to annihilate the well-constituted Government of his Country; neither can any People be happy by opposing and resisting their Sovereign in the Exercise of his just Rights and Prerogatives. That Maxim, THE SAFETY OF THE PEOPLE IS THE SƲPREME LAW must include (says Sanderson) the King in it, and that especially. It supposes there must be an unaccountable Authority in the Prince above all positive human Law; to whom it belongs to foresee and order, that the Commonwealth receive no damage, either through defect of Law, or through the too-superstitious Observation of it. Prelect. 10. de Conscient,

(N. 3.) In this Section you discourse, methinks, like one who has a mind to say something, though it be never so far from the Subject in ••• d. We are not here disputing about the Form of Go •••• ment, and yet you will needs, by the Head and S ••• lders, bring in your beloved Notion—That 'tis wholly left to the People to put themselves into this or that Form of Government, which they shall think fit to chuse. This is besides the business, and is also spoken of in it's proper place. What follows I cannot well reconcile to the Rules of Grammar. And all Government whatsoever, though after the mutual Tyes of Reciprocal Oaths, are not joyned by God, though permitted by him. If there be any meaning of these Words, I suppose it is, that all Government, as to the Form, is indifferent; and that none are bound by their Oaths to maintain the Government they live under, longer than it shall be to their good liking. If this be your meaning, I say, that this is not the proper place for you to insist upon this Principle. Nevertheless I return this short Answer. 1. That we do not find that God hath any where positively ordain'd any Form of Government, but that which is Monarchical. 2. That he who takes an Oath to be true and faithful to any lawful Form of Government, is bound to keep his Oath, till there shall happen an absolute Impossibility of performing; or they to whom he swore, shall loose him from his Obligation.

But now I am once again to account to this wise Expositor for wresting the Scripture. But how (says he) do you wrest the Scripture? And what's the Reason of this Emphatical Interrogation? Only because I apply this saying—What God hath joyned let no Man put asunder, to that near Conjunction there is betwixt the Head and the Members in Government, though 'tis indeed particularly spoken with Relation to Man and Wife, Matth. xix. 6. But, Sir, if this be to Wrest the Scripture, better and wiser Men than you or I do fall under this Condemnation. Some may call it Wresting the Scripture to quote the first Chapter of St. John for our Saviour's Divinity. And it seems as irksome to you to hear any Text
apply'd to that near Relation there is between the King and his Subjects; as it is to those to see any places of Scripture produc'd for our Lord's Divinity, which contain (as they think) no such thing. This Proposition, what God hath joyned let no Man put asunder, is indefinite; and may be properly apply'd to any two Relatives, which God hath joyned together, by such an inseparable Union as is not to be dissolv'd but by himself.

But, for disputation sake, you're pleas'd to grant, that King and People are joyned together by God. And upon this supposition you argue, that as a Wife may be put away for Fornication, so may a King forfeit his Right to his People by endeavouring to overthrow the Government, and Establish an Idolatrous Religion. This Argument will do you no Service, till you can produce some Text, wherein God hath as plainly allow'd a Divorce, betwixt a King and his Subjects, for misgovernment, as he has in this, betwixt Man and Wife in the case of Fornication. We read of many bad Kings amongst the Jews, but we do not find that the People were therefore permitted to depose them; no, not though they endeavoured to Establish an Idolatrous Religion. Besides, to make the Argument run Parallel, it rather lies thus; an Husband may put away his Wife for the Case of Adultery; therefore the King (who is Head of his People, as the Husband is of his Wife) may cut off an Idolatrous People, from the benefit of his Laws. At the end of this Paragraph you maintain, that the safety of the Body (i. e. the People) is to be valued before the Head (i. e. the cheif Governour.) And I agree with you, if you can convince me, that ever any body can be in health, or indeed can live, without its Head. But you go on; and give us this pleasant Reason for what you say, Because 'tis an easie matter to get an Head to the Body, but not a Body to the Head. Now, in my opinion, the one is every jot as easie as the other, and 'tis no less difficult to fit the Head with a Body, then 'tis to match the Body with an Head; that is, if they be once separated, 'tis absolutely impossible in nature to
find an Head to animate the Body, or a Body to serve the Head; and in Politics, 'twill be found very difficult so to adapt them, that they may live together in Peace, and good Correspondence with one another. The best way therefore is not to divide them; that neither the Head may be forc't to seek its Body, nor the Body its Head. 'Tis usual to cut off a corrupted and gangreen'd Member, when no Cure can be apply'd; but to sever the Head (though it be very sick) from the Body, or divide the whole Body (though full of Distempers) from the Head, is such a Method of Cure as never surely was Practised by any Chirurgeon. The Union betwixt them, is so close and necessary, that nothing but Death ought to loose and dissolve it.

(N. 4.) All that's here to be consider'd, is, Whether any force or violence have been used to King James? You say not, but others (as good Protestants as your self, and who had better opportunity of knowing the Truth in this matter) think otherwise. I do assure you, if we have taken up Arms against our Lawful Sovereign, we cannot vindicate our selves either by the Law of the Land, Nature or of Self-preservation. For the proof hereof I refer you to Sir Edward Cook in his Calvin's Case; and the Vindication of the Authority, &c. of the Church, Printed at Glascoe, p. 7, &c. p. 10, p. 35, &c.

(N. 5.) The People (you say) made the Law the Measure of their Privileges, in the business of the Ship-money. But how much soever the Law, at the first, might be on their sides, surely you will not deny, but that they stretch't their Priviledges beyond their due Bounds; when they did not only refuse to pay this Tax, but thence also took an occasion to rob the King of all those Prerogatives, wherewith, by Law, he was invested; and at last, of Life it self. Did their Priviledges Authorize them to lift up their hands against his Person, and imbrue them in the Blood of that Glorious Martyr. Suppose that King Charles the First was as Arbitrary, and every ways as evil a Prince, as his Rebellious Subjects represented him.
Yet shall Subjects (says the Homily against Disobedience. Part 1.) both by their wickedness provo •• God, for their deserved punishment, to give them an indiscree • and evil Prince; and also Rebel against him, and withal again ••
• od; who, for the punishment of their Sins, did give them su •• a Prince?

(N. 6, 7.) In my Answer to your 6th Proposition, I said, that Kings are God's Vicegerems, and that they who resist them, do resist the Ordinance of God, though the Person be a Claudius or a Nero. I say so still. To disprove this, you tell us, That a Vicegerent is one that i • appointed; but Kings (you say) are not appointed by God to 〈◊〉 the World, contrary to what you asserted in your 〈…〉 where you say, that even Jeroboam himself, was a King 〈…〉
•••• intment of Almighty God. But it was not for your turn 〈◊〉
•• y so in this place. For here you are to prove that Kings are not Vicegerents; and therefore in order to this conclusion, you contradict your self, and assume, that King's are not appointed by God, &c. Yet, as if you repented of what you have said, you alter your Note, and in the next Words, allow—That they may be properly called his Vicegerents, whilst they Administer Justice and Equity to every Man. But how if one or two, or some few of their Subjects should be wronged by them, must they be degraded, and fall from their Character of being God's Vicegerents for this defect of Justice and Equity? This, methinks, seems a little hard. But to let this pass; I'm glad to find that we are agreed so far. 'Tis some favour however that you'l grant, that good Kings may be very properly called God's Vicegerents, though you will not give this Title unto those that are bad, which yet I do not know how you can well deny, if you will own (what you have said) That Jeroboam was none of the best of Kings; and yet he was (you say) a King by the appointment of Almighty God.

To be a Vicegerent is to be in the stead, or to supply the place of another; and accordingly when we say, that Kings are God's Vicegerents, the meaning is, that they Act in his Name, and by his Authority: Which they may do, and yet
be themselves very bad Men. He who is invested with the Kingly Office, doth in many respects (recited at large by the Lawyers) resemble the Divinity, and is fitly styled God's Vicegerent, when yet he may fail very much in the Duty of his place. But if you will not be satisfied, that your King is God's Vicegerent, unless you can see the very Commission, which he hath immediately received from the hands of God himself, I confess, I know no more how to convince you, than I do an Atheist; who obstinately denies, that there is a God, because he never saw a miracle wrought, whereby his Existence was demonstrated to his Senses. If you be so scrupulous, I doubt, there never was, and never will be any King according to your mind, but such an one, as will acknowledge himself to be not God's, but the Peoples Vicegerent.

All that follows in this Paragraph, is a Declamation against Absolute Authority; which I tell you again, I do attribute to no King upon Earth, nor ever did any Sober Man. I say expresly, That Absolute and unconditionate Obedience is due only to God, who alone hath Absolute Authority. Nevertheless, the King as God's Vicegerent, being the highest Power upon Earth, ought to be obeyed in all things lawful, by a ready compliance; in things unlawful, by suffering for Conscience sake, rather than resist by Force of Arms. For, who can stretch forth his hand against the Lord's Anointed, and be guiltless? 1 Sam. xxvi. 9.

As a Comment upon which Text, hear what Bishop Sanderson says in his Twelfth Sermon ad Aulam. No conjuncture of circumstances whatsoever, can make that expedient at any time to be done, that is of it's self and in the kind unlawful, for a Man to Blaspheme the Holy Name of God, to Sacrifice to Idols, to give wrong Sentence in Judgment, by his Power to oppress those that are not able to withstand him, by Subtilty to over-reach others in bargaining, to take up Arms (offensive or defensive) against a lawful Sovereign, one of these and sundry other things of like nature being all of them simply, et de toto genere unlawful, may not be done by any Man, at any time, in any case, upon any colour or pretension whatsoever;
the express Command of God himself only excepted, as in the Case of Abraham for Sacrificing his Son; not for the avoiding of scandal, not at the instance of any Friend, or command of any Power upon Earth. Not for the maintenance of the Lives or Liberties either of our selves or others; not for the Defence of Religion; nor the Preservation of a Church or State; no, nor yet, if that could be imagin'd possible, for the Salvation of a Soul; no, not for the Redemption of the whole World.

I am now to clear my self from an Indictment which you draw up against me, of making God the Author or Approver of the Ʋsurpations of Men. This, I do assure you, I do absolutely deny; and could very easily retort it upon your self, if I should unravel all the pernicious Consequences of your popular Principle. But what you have here said shall not provoke me to it. Perhaps hereafter I may do it, if you shall give me occasion, by persisting in your false Calumnies and Malicious Aspersions. In the mean time, take this short Vindication of my self. God, 'tis most certain, is not the Author of Sin, neither doth he approve any wicked Practices; Yet he who should go about to kill his Father, or any ways to offer violence to him, because he is an habitual Drunkard, or Swearer, or (to come nearer to the Case) a very Tyrant in his Behaviour towards him; This would be not only to resist the Wickednesses, and unjust Rigor of the Father, but also the Ordinance of God; and by all good Christians, would be esteemed a breach of the V. Commandment: And 'tis no less so, I say still, to rise up in Arms against our lawful Prince, though the Person be a Claudius or a Nero. This later (though a Tyrant, a Persecutor, a Murtherer, and what not?) was included in that general Order which St. Paul gave to the Church. — Let Prayers and Supplications, &c. be made for Kings and all that are in Authority, &c. —And you must needs be Subject (said St. Peter) though Domitian (one every whit as bad as Claudius, and almost as ill as Nero) was then (as 'tis thought) the Roman Emperor. The King's Authority is so absolute, as it makes him unaccountable to his
People; never so Absolute as to give him a Right, any more than to one of his meanest Subjects, to do Violence, or Injustice to any Man. Absolute Authority, thus understood, did appertain to the Kings of Israel, although they were bound to observe the Law, not out of fear of being punish'd for their neglect, by the People, but by God himself. And thus the Kings of England, in Conscience towards God, are oblig'd to keep those good and wholsom Laws which are made for the benefit both of King and People, yet (do not deceive your felf) the English Presbytery has no more Power over the Kings of England, than the Levitical Priesthood had over the Kings of Israel.

The Imperial Crown and Jurisdiction of this Realm is (says Archbishop Cranmer in his Letter to Queen Mary) taken immediately from God, to be used under him only, and is Subject unto none but God alone; Apud Fox. tom. 3. p. 672. The People of England have no Power to judge their Kings, whether they be good or bad. If they have any such Authority, pray be so kind to your Friends, as to make out their Title; and shew, in what Capacity they may lawfully Exercise this Right. Is it, when some of the chiefest Daemagogues are assembled together, and call themselves an High Court of Commission? If so, then Bradshaw and his Associates did nothing but what was just, and King Charles the I. was in the wrong, when he refus'd to acknowledge their Jurisdiction. But this, I suppose, our Author himself, whatever he thinks, is scarce so hardy, as to maintain. Is this Power lodg'd in a Convention? That cannot be. For they who have no Power to judge concerning the least Matters, cannot certainly Judge and Condemn the King himself. But if it belongs neither to an High-Commission-Court, nor to a Convention to bind their Kings in Chains, This perhaps may be a priviledge which is peculiar to the Almighty and uncontroulable MOB. And truly, when 'tis lawful for every Man to do that which is lawful in his own Eyes (the special Prerogative of the Sovereign Mob) then, and not before, it will be lawful for the
Multitude, to judge which are good Kings and which are bad ones, and to execute their Judgment upon them, as they shall think fit. Thus, if we consider the People in all their Capacities, we cannot find this Authority in any of them; and therefore we must conclude, that there is, indeed, no such Power upon Earth; unless you can perswade us after all, that every such busy Fellow as your self may sit in the Seat of Judicature, and (having pronounc'd the King Guilty) loose the People from their Allegiance.

(N. 8, 9, 10, 11.) The Question (occasioned by your 11th. Maxim, Aphorism or Proposition, chuse how you will have it call'd) is, whether every Man has the Right of Self-preservation; as intirely under Civil Government, as in a State of Nature? You hold the Affirmative; I, the Negative. Now in order to come to a resolution in this Point. 1. It would be necessary to inquire whether indeed there ever was such a State of Nature, as you mean, in the World. I confess I much doubt it. For when, I pray, and where? In what Time, and Country, was this Libertine State to be found? For my part I never read of any such; neither is it reasonable to believe that God ever placed Men in such a confused State. For he who made all things in Number, Weight and Measure, never left Men (the best and most beautiful part of the Creation) without Laws and Government, and a mutual dependance upon one another. Adam's Sons (as soon as they were born) were under the Government of their Father, as his Dominion likewise was over all the other parts of the Creation. And had he continued in the State of Innocence, this orderly dependance of Inferiors upon their Superiors, would have been so free and unconstrain'd, that there would have been no Violence offer'd to any Man; and so the Principle of Self-preservation would have had nothing to have done in this Golden Age. This therefore cannot be the State of Nature which you mean. And as for that fictitious and imaginary Hypothesis, which Hobs lays down as the Ground and Foundation of his Antichristian Politicks, 'tis a meer Phantasm
(to use one of his own Words) of his own, quite besides the intention of God and Nature. Yet this Leviathan-State, this Hobbian-Republick must be the State you mean, when you say—Every Man has the Right of Self preservation as intire, under Civil Government, as in a State of Nature. Supposing therefore such a State, let us, 2. consider the truth of what you say. Now in this State all Men you know have (according to Mr. Hob's Doctrine) a Right to all things; and therefore every Man (in this blessed State) has a Right to kill every other Man, who shall offer to oppose him in the acquisition of his just Right (as he thinks it) and not suffer him to become an Universal Proprietor of all the World. Now I hope you will yield that this unlimited Right (or rather boundless Lust) is restrain'd under Civil Government, when the Power of the Sword is lodg'd in the Hands of the Supreme Magistrate; For the punishment of Evil doers, and for the praise of them that do well. Men's private Reason is not now to be their measure in righting or preserving themselves; but the publick Reason of the Community, must give such bounds and limits to their indefinite desires, as may most conduce to the good of the whole. Private Persons (whatever Right of Self-preservation they might have in the State of Nature) after they are incorporated into Civil Society, have no more than the Law doth allow; and that, in all Governments, upon Computation, will be found much less than Mr. Hobs's State-of-nature-men do arrogate to themselves.

(N. 12.) You now grow Angry, and breath Vengeance and Antichristian Principles against Passive Obedience; which never did you, nor any body else any harm. Why so furious? Be not so passionate. For (as the Italian says) Molto cattivo geudice è l'affetto. Passion is the worst Judge in the World. Whilst you give way to it, I can expect neither fair dealing, nor any good Sense from you.—The Point to be examined, is, whether more Throats have been cut by the Doctrine of Passive Obedience, or that of Resistance? You say the former has been more guilty, in this Particular. And to prove your Opinion,
you appeal to the Cruel Persecutions under the Roman Emperors, the Massacres of Paris, Piedmont and Ireland. Now I am so far from being of your mind, That I do verily believe, that the Doctrine of Passive Obedience did never cut any Man's Throat, and has been always Innocent both in the time of the Roman Persecutions, and more modern Massacres. As for the Roman Persecutions, The Primitive Christians, 'tis certain, had deeply imbibed the Doctrine of Passive Obedience. They were fully perswaded, that they could resist without Sin; and therefore pay'd a willing Submission to the Emperor's Coerceive Power, when they flatly deny'd to do what he Commanded. And thus the Passive Doctrine brought many to the glorious Crown of Martyrdom; but I never read, that it ever cut any one's Throat, or took upon it self, by War and Violence, to dispose the Crowns of this World. You may as well Condemn the Doctrine, of not doing evil that good may come of it, for cutting Throats, as this of Submission in all Cases, to the higher Powers. And in truth these two are so nearly related, that they must needs live and dye, stand and fall together.

As for the Massacres of Paris, Piedmont and Ireland, if those Protestants were Butchered for their Religion, when by their unanimous Resistance they might have sav'd themselves, they dye Martyrs in a good Cause. But if the Dragoons and Tories fell upon them on a sudden when they did not expect a Persecution, and were unable to make any Resistance, The Doctrine of Passive-Obedience cannot be Arraign'd, as guilty of their Deaths. Yet woe be to their Persecutors, by whom such an irreparable offence was given to the Christian Religion.

But now you come up nearer to me, and suppose at least, the contrary (i. e. that more Throats have been cut by the Doctrine of Resistance, than that of Passive Obedience) but the Sin (you say) lies at their doors, who by their cruel Persecutions, and violation of the Rights of the People, force them to right themselves. You mean, force them to Rebel. Now I do affirm, that no
Man was ever forc'd to commit Sin; and that Rebellion is a Sin, all Men must acknowledge, who do not esteem Witchcraft as a Vertue. They therefore, who Rebel because the Prince is a Tyrant, and endeavours unjustly to take away their Lives; are far from being guiltless, though they have the greatest Provocations imaginable. Such Princes are deservedly odious in the sight of God and Man; yet their Subjects ought not to resist by Force of Arms: For this would be to oppose one Sin by another. And besides, would make it an impossible thing, that there should be any such thing, as Persecution, for Righteousness-sake. For when Subjects are too strong for their Prince, they may, nay (according to this Principle) they ought to resist, rather than suffer. And when they are too weak, they suffer only because they cannot help it; which is no Vertue at all. For there can be no Persecution for Righteousness-sake, which is not undertaken, and endured with Freedom, Chearfulness, and Voluntary Submission to every Ordinance of Man for the Lord's sake.

The rest of this Section, you spend in raveing, and talking wildly without reason, order and coherence. I have no mind to expose you, though you do give sufficient occasion for a Man to lay you open to the World; as one who has Sacrificed both his Wit and Judgment to his Passion and false Notions of Government; which Education and Interest, have deeply imprinted on his mind. We ought not to defend our Religion, when the Laws of the Country are against it. This is one of your Propositions. Which, I confess, sounds very odly in mine Ears. If we ought not to defend our Religion, when the Laws of the Country are against it; when, I pray, ought we to defend it? But your meaning is, I suppose, that we ought not to defend our Religion by Force of Arms, when the Laws of the Country are against it. Neither ought we, after this manner to defend it, when the Laws of the Country are for it. But the Scripture (you say) does not require us not to defend our Religion (or civil Rights) Establish'd by the Laws of the Country. Here you touch this point so tenderly, as if you was conscious, that it will not abide a
thorough Examination—The Scripture does not require us not to defend— Our Religion or Civil Rights. The first of these Expressions mollifies your Doctrine of Resistance very much. For if the Scripture does not require us not to defend, then the Scripture does not positively require us to defend, &c. And so we seem to be agreed thus far, that the Doctrine of Resistance is not taught in the Scripture. The second way of expressing your self alters the State of the Question, and makes it altogether ambiguous. Our Religion or Civil Rights—as if our Religion and Civil Rights were the same thing; and a Man could not enjoy the one without the other. I wish you would inform us, how this wonderful Transmutation is to be made. If you have an Art to turn Property into Religion, and make gain to be Godliness, you ought to be more sought after, than any Chymist of them all, who is verè adeptus, and has attain'd the Secret of turning Metals into Gold. But perhaps you may think me too light. To be more serious therefore; I Answer, that the Scripture medles not with Mens Civil Rights: and as for Religion, it has prescrib'd a way to secure it, without such defence, as (in all probability) will ruin both our Religion and Civil Rights. A Christian boldness in confessing the Truth, and Patient suffering for it, is the best and only lawful means of throwing off the Tyranny and Yoke of Antichrist, if laid upon the Necks of Subjects, by their lawful Sovereigns. (Oxford Ʋniversity's Reasons against the Covenant drawn up by Bishop Sanderson p. 210, 211.)

But if we may not defend our Religion, any Army or Number of Heathens may come, and settle their false Religion here. No, Sir! 'Tis lawful and our Duty to resist a Foreign Prince, who unjustly Invades his Neighbours Country, let his pretence be what it will. But if our Religion and Rights should be Invaded by our own lawful Prince, then earnest Prayers to God, humble Supplications to the King, unfeigned Repentance, and Amendment of our Lives are the only proper Weapons of our Christian Defence. If a Foreign Power (says Dr. C.) opposes our King, he is a Robber: If he be a Subject, who rises against his
Sovereign, he hath renounc'd Christianity with his Allegiance, and is to be esteemed a Troubler of our Israel. Therefore whatsoever they be that are Enemies to the King, and whatsoever the pretence be, we wish they may never prosper. Comp. to the Temple, Part 1. p. 177. Thus doth this worthy Author Answer both your Cases—that of a Foreign Prince, and that of our own Sovereign. And as to the later, that is, the point of Resistance, if our Religion and Rights should be Invaded, by our own Prince; be pleas'd to consult the D. of C's. Excellent Letter to the Lord Russel.

The eminent Man of whom you have heard (and whose Name you seem to be ignorant of, tho' you Appeal to his Book) was one Lucifer Calaritanus, who wrote a Book de Regibus Apostaticis; wherein he has spoken some things which shew him to have been a Person of more zeal and warmth, than temper and Christian moderation. This Book I do not find approved by St. Athanasius, as containing Orthodox Doctrine; though he did indeed recommend the Two Books, which were Written by the same Author, in behalf of himself against the Emperor Constantius: But these Books were Written before Julian the Apostate came to the Empire; and so could not be occasioned by his telling the Christians, that their Doctrine was to suffer.

Having thus made some Reflections upon your loose and incoherent Sayings, I should now examin your Interpretation of several Texts of Scripture; which Province I wish you would leave unto those who are better able to manage it. Let a Socinian be the Interpreter, and the Scripture shall speak nothing but his Sense. And if one of Seditious Principles be allow'd to comment upon the Bible, we shall be sure to find nothing therein but comfortable Doctrine for those who despise Dominion, and speak evil of Dignities. I shall here insert your Explications of the Texts alledged in one Column, and their true meaning (as the most Ancient and Orthodox Expositors have understood them) in another; that the Reader may have an Antidote against your Poyson.

div.head: The Author's Comment or Paraphrase.
div.p: WHere the Word of a King is (according to the Law or Custom of the Country) there is Power, and who may say unto him, what do'st thou?

Submit your selves to every Law of Man, for the Lord's sake, whether it be to the King as cheif Executor of the Laws, or unto Officers appointed by the King, for the Executing, or fulfilling of the Laws.

Let every Soul be Subject to the Laws, or Customs of the Country; and to the Prince as Executor thereof: For the greatest Villain amongst Mankind, acts by the Power of Almighty God; but not by his Appointment, or Approbation. The Power which every Man hath, is from God. They therefore that resist the Laws, resist the Powers (beyond which a Prince hath no Power)—For he is the Minister of God for good, whilst he administers Justice, and Equity to every Man; and punisheth him that doth evil, or violates the Laws. Wherefore ye must needs (if the Laws be against you) suffer according to the Laws of the Country, though never so unreasonable. Render therefore to all their Dues; Tribute, Custom, Fear and Honour to whom it is due by the Laws of the Land.

div.head: Observations upon the Author's Expositions.
div.p: I. I Observe upon his first Paraphrase, That (which he himself confesses) the King's of Israel were absolute and unaccountable to the People, for their Actions; whether they were good or bad; whether they were according to the Law of God (the only Law and Custom of that Country) or no: And therefore their Commands, 'tis plain, were not to be disputed ore gladij, by the Sword's point, though they were never so unjust: And consequently though the Author's Exposition is true, yet it is not full, and doth not reach the true intent and meaning of the Words.

I Observe II. That if St. Peter by every ordinance of Man, means every Law of Man, then the Words must run thus—Submit your selves to every Law of Man for the Lord's sake; whether it be to the King as the Supream Law, &c. And if this be so, what will become of the People's Title to judge and dethrone their King? Thus our Author outwits himself, and in effect destroys the Principle, which he pretends to maintain. But Secondly, I suppose his meaning is, that both
the Laws and King's are made by the People, and are both so far to be submitted unto, as they have the People's consent, and good likeing; and no farther. But neither will this Comment agree with the Text. For thus, the Apostle should rather have exprest himself after this manner. Submit your selves to every Law of Man (not for the Lord's, but) for the Peoples sake, so that still we are at a loss, how to make the Words hit with our Author's Sense: And we are more to seek, how to make them consistent with St. Paul's: who expresly teaches, that there is no Power but of God. But our Expositor is, I believe, not much concern'd whether St. Peter be consistent, either with himself, or his Brother Apostle St. Paul; 'tis enough, he thinks, if he can but hale his Words into his own Opinion, and fit them to that System of Government, which he hath form'd to himself; which yet, he hath not done.

I Observe III. That in his Paraphrase upon St. Paul's Words, he will needs still divide the Higher Powers, betwixt the Laws, and the Prince; whereas nothing is more plain, then that the Apostle speaks of Men (and not Laws) invested with Regal Authority. Secondly, He seems to insinuate, that the Power of the meanest Person, is as much from God, as that of a Supream, Independent Prince. The Power (says he) which every Man
hath is from God. Thirdly, He has thought fit to say nothing at all to the great Sanction, of this Christian Law, concerning Submission to the Supream Authority — And they that resist, shall receive to themselves damnation. This was too hot for him to touch. I pray God, that he may never feel the smart of it hereafter. Fourthly, He tells us, we must needs suffer according to the Laws of the Country (if they be against us) tho never so unreasonable. Now for my part, I think there is little difference, whether a Man suffers by unreasonable Laws, or the Arbitrary and unreasonable Edicts of a Sovereign Prince, as the Primitive Christians did. Nay, If I must suffer, I should rather chuse the later than the former way. For unreasonable Laws (if made by the general consent of the People) shew, that the generality of the People are so too, who would consent to such Laws; and therefore 'tis not probable that they will, in a little time, be brought to acknowledge their Error, and repeal these unreasonable Laws; so that a Man may languish under them, as long as he lives, and his posterity after him, without any redress. But a Sovereign Prince is but one Person; and he, it's likely, may more easily be perswaded to revoke his unreasonable Edicts; or Death may take him off, and prevent him (sooner than a Body of Men) from Executing what he designs. Fifthly
and Lastly, our Author makes no difference betwixt Obedience and Subjection, which he ought to do. For thus all pretence of Resistance will be taken away, and yet the Subject secur ••
• rom committing Sin, by an actual Obedience to any sinful or unlawful Command. Whereas, if Absolute Submission be not a Duty, when active Obedience is not, we may resist by Force of Arms; and so, do evil that good may come of it; directly contrary bo •• to the Apostolical Precept, and Practise.

div.head: The Texts of Scripture.
div.p: WHere the Word of a King is, there is Power; and who may say unto him, what do'st thou? Eccles. viii. 4.

Submit your selves to every Ordinance of Man, for the Lord's sake; whether it be to the King as Supream; or unto Governors, as unto them that are sent by him; for the punishment of Evil Doers, and for the praise of them that do well. 1 Pet. 11, 13, 14.

Let every Soul be Subject to the Higher Powers. For there is no Power, but of God. The Powers that be, are ordain'd of God. Who so therefore resisteth the Ordinance of God; and they that resist shall receive to themselves damnation. For Rulers are not a Terror to good Works, but to the evil. Wilt thou not be afraid of the Power? Do that which is good; and thou shal't have praise of the same. For he is the Minister of God to thee for good: But if thou do that which is evil, be afraid: For he beareth not the Sword in vain: For he is the Minister of God, a Revenger to execute wrath upon him that doth evil. Wherefore ye must needs be Subject, not only for wrath, but Conscience sake; for this cause pay you tribute also: For they are God's Ministers attending continually upon this very thing. Therefore render to all their Dues;
Tribute to whom Tribute is due; Custom to whom Custom; Fear to whom Fear; Honour to whom Honour. Rom. xiii. 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7.

This Doctrine of Obedience, the Author of the enquiry into the present State of Affairs, calls St. Paul's System of Government; as if the Apostle made Systems of Government, as the Astronomers do of the Heavens. This expression seems a little too light and Philosophical in so serious a matter. But that which is more remarkable, is, that having set down these Seven Verses, as if they were self-evident and needed no further Explication, he only adds his decisive Judgment upon them, as follows—in these Words we have the Duty of the Magistrate, as well as the Obedience of the Subject set forth, and so mixt together, that we must conclude, that upon the Total failing of the one, the other does likewise cease. The Duty indeed of the Magistrate as well as the Obedience of the Subject, is set forth in these Words; but here's not a Word of the Subjects Obedience ceasing, if the Magistrate shall not perform his Duty. Nay, St. Paul, 'tis evident, had no design to teach any such Doctrine, but only to lay down a certain and Eternal Rule of Christian Obedience to the Supream Powers,
though they did never so much abuse their Power. For had his intent been to have inculcated upon them this Principle — That Obedience ceases, upon the Total Failing of the Magistrate to perform his Duty; he would in effect, have Preach't to them Sedition and Rebellion, instead of Submission and Obedience. For the Emperor, then in Possession, was one of the worst, that ever was; and if ever any Prince, Totally fail'd in his Duty, he certainly did. Yet notwithstanding, that he was so very bad, he gives them not the least liberty to disobey; but on the contrary puts them in mind, more than once, of that good which they did and might receive under his Government, though he himself, was one of the worst of Men.— But if Obedience do Totally cease upon the Total failing of he Magistrate to perform his Duty, I would gladly know when it may be adjudged, that the Magistrate doth Totally fail in his Duty? Is it, when he notoriously violates the Law of Nature? No, that cannot be: For the Emperor, when this Epistle to the Romans was Written, did so, in the highest degree. Is it, because he Persecutes Christianity? Not this neither: For this Emperor did so. Is it, because he endeavours, to subvert the Laws of the Land? Not so neither: For how can this be a greater Crime, than the notorious violations of the
Laws of Nature, and the Persecution of Christianity. What therefore is this Total failure, and wherein doth it consist? Surely it can be nothing else but when a Prince is Totally depriv'd either of Reason, or of Life. And in this Sense I grant the Subjects Obedience to that Individual Person must needs cease. We are then at last come to this, that in case of Lunacy, or Phrensy, or Death, the Subjects Obedience ceases, and no otherwise. The last of these doth naturally dissolve the Relation between a Prince and the People; and the other two by a moral necessity; if by many, repeated and habitual actions they can be undeniably proved in the Face of the whole World; yet so, as that, where the Government is hereditary, it shall be put into the hands of a Guardian, one or more; as in the Case of Infancy. But now none of these Cases will serve the design of the enquiry. But however, the business was done as effectually, as if he, who stood in the way betwixt some Person's Ambition and the Crown, had been either an Ideot or a Madman; in his Cradle, or his Grave. But it was at this time necessary to tell the People, that the Magistrate had Totally fail'd in his Duty: And then we must, forsooth! needs conclude (not from St. Paul's Words which intimate no such thing, but from our own lusts, which we call
the necessity of present Affairs) that upon the Total failing of the Magistrate's Duty, the Subject's Obedience does likewise cease. But my Soul! come not thou into their Secrets. And may I never be one of those jolly Casuists, who to serve a present turn, will at least, endanger not only the damnation of themselves, but their Neighbours also. I confess, that I have not strength of thought enough, to manage such an hardy enterprise, as this is.

div.head: The true Sense and Meaning of these Places of Scripture.
div.p: WHere the Word of a King is, there is Power; the Commands of a Sovereign Prince proceed from one who Acts in the Name, and by the Authority of God Almighty, And who may say unto him what do'st thou? And who can call him to an account for his Actions.

Submit your selves to every ordinance of Man, if you cannot actively obey, yet at least submit your selves to all Superiour Magistrates, for the Lord's sake (by whose Authority they Act) whether it be to the King (next under God) in all Causes and over all Persons, Supream; or unto Governors, as unto them, that are sent by him, Ministers Commissioned by him for the punishment of evil doers, a • d for the praise of them that do well: The end for which both the King and his Ministers are appointed by God; which yet, if they shall not fulfil, you must nevertheless Submit, for the Lord's sake.

Let every Soul be Subject to the Higher Powers. Let every Person, of what quality, rank and condition soever, be Subject to the King and his Subordinate Ministers. For there is no Power but of God. For both the King (or Emperor) and they who Act under him, are Authorized by God himself. The Powers that be, are ordain'd of God. The Emperor and his Ministers are (I say again) invested with their Authority by the God of Order. Whoso therefore resisteth the Power (they who by force and violence, oppose
the Emperor and his Ministers) resisteth the Ordinance of God (do oppose or fight against that Order which God himself hath Establish'd amongst Men) And they that resist shall receive to themselves damnation. And they that do thus oppose God in his Ministers, shall be severely judged. This free and voluntary Subjection is a good Work; and though you may suffer by it, yet having the Testimony of a good Conscience, you will have no cause to fear the Magistrates Power: For Rulers are not a terror to good Works but to the evil. For not they who do good, but they who do evil, have reason to be afraid of their Governors— Wil'st thou then not be afraid of the Power? Wil'st thou behave thy self so, as not to have any just fear of thy Rulers Power? Do that which is good. Act as a good Christian ought to do in all Cases; especially in this instance, of dutiful Submission to the Emperor, and all in Authority under him; And thou shalt have praise of the same. By this means thou wil'st, it's probable (however thou oughtest to) gain his favour. For He is the Minister of God to thee for good. For the Power which God hath given him, is design'd for thy encouragement in well doing: But if thou do that which is evil (by resisting his Power, and other evil practises) Be afraid (thou hast cause to be afraid) For he beareth not the Sword in vain, which he would do, did he not punish all Rebellious, and wicked practises of what kind soever. For he is the Minister of God, a Revenger to Execute wrath upon him that doth evil (whether by resisting his Authority, or otherwise) wherefore ye must needs be Subject (so that there is a necessity of this Absolute Submission) not only for wrath, but Conscience sake (not only for fear of punishment, but out of the Sense of your Duty, which you owe to your Sovereign Prince, for the Lord's sake) For, for this Cause, pay you Tribute also: Now, that you ought to submit not only for fear of Punishment, but for Conscience sake, appears from the Taxes which are Levy'd upon you, and which you're oblig'd in Duty to pay: For they are God's Ministers attending continually upon this very thing. For (once more I tell you) all Sovereign Powers are ordain'd by God for the good of the World, which they ought carefully to attend—Render therefore to all their Dues; Tribute to whom Tribute is due; Custom to whom Custom; Fear to whom Fear, Honour to whom Honour. Render therefore unto all what justly belongs unto them; Trib • te, Custom, Fear and Honour to the Emperor and his Ministers; unto whom they are more especially due, both by the Divine and Imperial Laws.

And now for a more full answer to your Paraphrase, and all that follows in this long Paragraph, I refer you to the Reverend D. P's Paraphrase, upon Proverbs; which you'l find faithfully quoted in the History of Passive Obedience, p. 84. —And since my saying, This is right Commonwealth Rhetoric, hath chaft you into all this heat, and made you spend so many unnecessary words, let me direct you to another Learned Author who runs the Parallel between the deposing Doctrine of the Church of Rome, and the Commonwealth Principles, in these Three Particulars. (1.) In setting up a Court of Judicature over Sovereign Princes. (2.) In breaking the Oaths and Bonds of Allegiance Men had entered into. (3.) In justifying Rebellion on the account of Religion. Jesuite's Loyalty. History of Passive Obedience, p. 133.

I shall now leave the Impartial Reader to judge, whether you or I may be justly charg'd for having wrested the Scriptures. Nay, Sir, be your self the Judge, whether I have not given the true and genuine Interpretation of these Texts? And whether you be not Self-condemn'd, and a Wrester of Scripture by your own Rules? Your charge runs in these words. —What a Sin are you and all other Men for Passive Obedience Guilty of, that wrest the Scriptures, which were appointed for the Suffering State of Christianity, whilst under Heathen Princes and without Laws to support them; and compare them to the present Circumstances? Here you manifestly yield, that the Interpretation of the Scriptures, which most favours the Doctrine of Passive-Obedience, is most agreeable to the Suffering State of Christianity, whilst under Heathen Princes, and without Laws to support them. Now 'tis certain, that all the whole New Testament was Written during this Suffering State of Christianity. Judge therefore, whether they who interpret it in this Sense, do not give the true, proper, immediate and genuine Meaning of it or no? If it be to wrest the Scriptures, to explain and apply them as they were intended, then indeed we who are for Passive Obedience are Guilty of this Sin,
but if this be to deal truly and faithfully with Men in the great Concern of their Souls, then we are not to blame: but those cannot be excused, who, to serve a turn, Wrest and Wiredraw the Scriptures from their Original and Primitive Signification: as if there was one Sense of them for the Suffering State of Christianity, and another for the present Circumstances.
(N. 13.) The People (I agree) are not bound actively to obey any Commands of their Prince, which are repugnant to the Laws of God and the Land.

(N. 14.) The Oath of Allegiance, or Corporation Oath (after all your tossing and tumbling to cast it off) sticks close to you; and (like a faithful Monitor) is continually at your Elbow, to warn you, that you must never rebel, let the pretence be what it will. What can be more plain, than the words themselves—I do swear, &c. That it is not lawful upon any pretence whatsoever to take up Arms, &c. Yet this Oath (you may be sure) was not designed for our ruine. It doth indeed cut off all hopes of destroying the Monarchy, if Men would keep their Oaths; and to such as are given to change, it may indeed be grievous, but to none others, who desire to live quiet and peaceable Lives in all godliness and honesty. This Oath doth not (as you would have us to believe) make the King a Tyrant by Law, neither doth it allow him to be such: but it hinders Subjects from being Rebels, and will not allow them to be such against all Law, Reason and Christianity. For a Rebel is worse than the worst Prince, and Rebellion is worse than the worst Government of the worst Prince that hitherto hath been. Hom. against Obed. Part. 1. In short, this Oath is agreeable to the Doctrine of our Church ever since the Reformation. No Subjects may draw their Swords against their Prince for any cause whatsoever it be; say Cranmer, Ridley, Redman and other Worthies of our Church, in their Declaration of the Christian Doctrine, An. 1537.

(N. 15.) If Negative Resistance (as you here define) is to disobey the Commands of the Prince, when according to Law,
Then David by flying from Saul (which you say in your first Paper, was his negative Resistance) did disobey Saul's Commands, when according to Law. How these things can be reconcil'd I desire to be inform'd. As for David's 600 Men, though they might not be all intended for Spies and Scouts; yet the overplus might be no more than one in his Circumstances (being Heir apparent to the Crown) might reasonably keep about him for his Guard. As for Athaliah, 'tis sure, that she was an Usurper, and 'tis most probable, that therefore she was depos'd, and not for Murthering the King's Sons, and her other Acts of Cruelty: for many other Princes were very cruel and unjust, and yet we do not read that they were depos'd.

(N. 16.) Neither an Invasion actually made, nor eminently feared by a Foreign Power, doth Authorize Subjects to depose their King. This is my Proposition. To which you answer? We have not depos'd the King, &c. That he is, by force, dispossest of his Throne 'tis certain, call it by what new Term of Art you please. However we may endeavour to palliate the matter, the Papists (we may be sure) will say, 'tis neither better nor worse than Deposing our King; and that, we do now seem to be agreed with them in this Point; how severely soever we have formerly condemn'd it. And I am sorry, That Christians, and Protestants, and Church-of-England-men, should give them this occasion to account us their Proselytes, by the Practice of that Doctrine, wherein we were before, so visibly distinguish'd. Hoc Ithacus velit, &c.

But if King James (you tell us) had kept the Law, he never had lost his Rights, &c. Sir! neither you nor I know this; for they who neither love nor fear their King, will always find some pretence or other to be rid of him, whether he keeps the Law or not. But taking it for granted, that King James did violate the Law in as high a degree as you would perswade us he did: Is this a sufficient Warrant for us to break the Law and our Oaths too? Where then is our Subjection for Conscience sake? Where is our Obedience for the Lord's sake?
This is a Doctrine, which we ought heartily to detest as false and scandalous in the Supposition; and in the Inference seditious and devilish. How defective soever the King may be in performing his part, this doth not excuse our neglect, or discharge us from our Obligations.

The publick quiet and safety requires, that he who robs another Man, or fires an House, should suffer Death for so doing. But that it is for the publick benefit, that Kings should be accountable to their Subjects, and punish'd by them for their Misdemeanours, this I utterly deny, unless you can shew, that it is for the publick good, to act directly contrary to God's Commandment. 'Tis a greater Evil (all things consider'd) to depose bad Kings, than to suffer the ill Consequences of their Misgovernment: and besides, 'tis Rebellion against God himself as well as his Vicegerent. And notwithstanding whatever his Holiness Pope Hildebrand, and the Reverend Fathers of the Society have Taught or Practis'd to the contrary; This is, and ever will be a most certain truth; For Subjects to resist their Sovereign Prince upon any pretence whatsoever, is unlawful and impious.

Your silly and improper instance of a Father's disinheriting his Eldest Son, is not worth taking notice of. It supposes forsooth, the People to be the Father, and the King, as their Son; A good Child indeed, so long as he behaves himself as he ought to do; otherwise the Rod is ready for him, and he must be whip'd. I am asham'd of such indecent and fulsom Comparisons. I agree, that Our Constitution is the happiest in the World; but by such State-menders as your self, I pray God, it doth not become one of the worst in Christendom.

If all be true, that you say, of King James—That he took upon him the whole Authority—That he made himself the sole Fountain of the Government—That he govern'd by his Absolute Will and Pleasure, &c. Yet from all these Premises, it doth not follow— That his Subjects are absolv'd from the Oath of Allegiance, as much as if he was actually dead, and had sign'd a Resignation of
his Crown. For the Crown of England is Imperial, and no Forfeiture can be made, by any degree of Male-Administration. The King of England is as much a King before he has taken the Coronation-Oath, as after: And if he shall neglect to perform it, after he has taken it, the Government doth not therefore lapse to the People. And to argue otherwise, is to reason like a Man, who neither understands the uncontestable Rights of our Kings, nor the Duty of his Subjects. The Regal Authority remains, though the King abuses his Power; and the Duty of Subjects is not dissolv'd, though he extends his Authority beyond the just Rights of a King.

In the next place, you fall upon the Topick of Resignation, and Desertion of the Government. This Argument has been so throughly skan'd, and so judiciously manag'd by the Author of the Desertion discus'd, that it seems to be wholly forsaken. Your ablest Pens cannot maintain this Cause: Let me therefore advise you by no means to undertake it. Before you venture so dogmatically to determine, that, what King James did was a publick Resignation of his Throne to the Nation; you should consult the Historians for some Parallel Instance, which has been adjudg'd, and generally receiv'd as a Resignation. But because you present us with no such Example, I shall take it for granted, that there is none of that Nature; at least, that you know of none such. The Case of Edward the IV. seems to have been the most like that of King James; and yet it was never judg'd to have been a Desertion, Resignation, or Abdication; neither was it ever call'd by any of these hard Names. I shall give it you, as 'tis related by Philip de Comines, a Person of good Account amongst the Historians both for his Judgement and Integrity. He tells us, that, Edward the IV. being deserted by his Soldiers, was overpower'd by the increasing greatness of the Earl of Warwick: That therefore he was forc'd, for his own Security, to make his escape into Holland first, and afterwards into Burgundy: That, he soon after returned into England; And, though he brought no great Force with him, yet by the revolt of the
Duke of Clarence (King Edward's Brother) with 12000 Men from the Earl of W. to the King's Party, he becam • so strong, that he defeated the Earl in a pitch'd Battle; and in 21 Days recovered his Kingdom, whic • the Earl of W. had taken from him in Eleven. Now the Plea of Abdication or Desertion was never made use of against King Edward the IV. though it might, as plausibly, have been objected against him, as it is now against King James the II. For he went away (as appears by the story) with as great Precipitation, and as much Surprise to his People, as King James did. And he appointed no body to officiate in his stead, when he was gone; neither did he take any care for the Administration of the Government in his absence, Phil. Comin. p. 92, 93, 94, &c. Engl. Edict.

You go on, and ask, What can be said for Scotland? I also put the same Question. And you must give us a more satisfactory Answer, than you have yet return'd to it, or we must conclude that in truth, nothing can be said for Scotland; with what forehead can you say that King James was never lawful King of Scotland, if he never took the Coronation-Oath? Has it not always been an undoubted Truth received by our Lawyers, That the King of Great Britain, is so, before he has taken the Oaths? As for that Absolute Authority, by which, you say, he govern'd in Scotland; upon inquiry, I believe, it will not be found so Absolute, as you would rep •• sent it; and, if it was; whether it was therefore reasonable as well as necessary, to throw off this Arbitrary and Ʋnlawful Governour, you, I presume, are not so well vers'd in the Constitution of that Kingdom, as that we may securely rely upon your Judgment in the Case.

And the same Question, which you put about Scotland, you may also propose concerning Ireland. For the Irish (when the King left England, were (as at other times) governed by his Deputy-Leiutenant, and so his going away could have no Impression upon that Nation. Thus have you raised Objections, which all that you're able to say, can never conjure down again.

Well! but if no Forfeiture can be made, what must be done? what Anarchy? what Confusion? what Ruine and Destruction to the utter extirpation of our Civil Rights and Religion, destroying many 1000 Souls, &c. must have follow'd? In answer to all which, I could easily represent the Tragical Consequences of Deposing, in a much more dismal Dress. All these sad things which you mention, Anarchy, Confusion, Ruine, the loss of our Civil Rights and Religion, destruction of many 1000 Souls, will inevitably follow the deposing Practice; besides, that which is more to be fear'd than all these, Eternal Damnation. 'Tis needless to enlarge upon this Subject; both you and I have talk'd more, than the Reader (if he has not very little to do) will have cause to thank us for. Yet I cannot conclude this Section without taking notice, of that unbecoming Irony, which you pass upon the Prayers and Patient Submission of the Church, in the Case of a bad Prince; who will not observe his Oath. We must (say you) e'ne have set down and cryed, Lord have mercy upon us, and expect (have expected) our deliverance by Miracle, though Miracles are ceas'd. Sir! you seem to be a Man not much given to Wit; and I wish (for your own sake as well as Christianity in general) that you had not vented it upon this occasion. Though Miracles are ceas'd, yet the Doctrine of our Blessed Saviour and his Apostles do still remain and shall continue for ever. Though Miracles are ceass'd, yet, I hope you will not say, that God's Providence is also ceas'd. Tho Miracles are ceas'd, yet his care over his Church is not ceas'd. Had we sate down and cry'd, Lord, have mercy upon us, as we ought to have done; God would have been glorified by our Sufferings; and, in his good time, he would have rescu'd us from them, without a Miracle. When the edge of Sovereign Authority is turn'd against us, then to cry unto the Lord in our distress, is no such despicable means of Deliverance as you may imagine. I have read of some Tyrants, who have been more afraid of the Prayers of good Men, than of all the armed force of their Enemies; but I never met with any good Christian, who trusted more to his
Temporal, than his Spiritual Weapons; and thought it in vain to betake himself to his Prayers, if he might not, at the same time, second them with his Sword. Believe me, Sir, or rather beleive the whole Primitive Church, that there can be no better opposition against a Tyrant, than the amendment of our Lives, and constant Prayers to God. Though Miracles are ceas'd, yet, for the sake of our common Christianity, do not despise, a Lord! have mercy upon us.

N. 17.) Here you state the difference betwixt the Authority of a Private Person and a King. And, if your Politicks hold good, 'tis only this—That a Private Person has no Authority at all, but to live according to the Laws; whereas a King is an Executor of the Laws. A wonderful discovery! for which surely you expect no less, than that all Kings should return you their thanks; and reward you, for this great Invention. I would fain (as you tell me) set the King above the Laws, but I'm sure your Hypothesis places him under them. I had thought that 'tis the Prince, who gives life and breath to the Law, and that his Le Roy Le Veut, signifies something more than to be a meer Executor of the Law; which every petty Constable is, in his proper District. The King, 'tis true, is Executor of the Laws; but let it be always remember'd, that he is Supreme Executor and Legislator too.

N. 18, 19. The matter to be inquired into, is, What makes a true and real King? I say, he that ascends the Throne by a regular Title, is a true and real King. No, say you. 'Tis Possession, taking the Coronation-Oath and governing according to Law, which makes a true and real King. Let the matter be argued; 'Twill be granted, I suppose, that he is a true and real King, whose Title is neither Defective, nor Counterfeit; and that his Title who comes regularly to the Throne is thus qualified. I conclude therefore that such an one is a true and real King. As for Possession, taking the Coronation-Oath, governing according to Law, these Titles, taken either separately or altogether, do not exclude all defect, and counterfeit. A Man may take Possession
by Vi • lence; He may swear to govern according to Law, and also Rule according to his Oath; yet his Title may be d • fective, 〈◊〉
• hat of the House of Lancaster was; and it may b •
•••• te • f • it, as Simnel's and Warbeck's had been, had these 〈◊〉 oft •• ever been crown'd.

〈◊〉 for your Instances of Sigisbert King of W. Saxons, that of Edw • rd the II. and the other of Richard the II. 'tis not two or three Presidents in 7 or 800 Years time, that can make a Right; much less can these Examples (always condemn'd but when they serve a turn) prejudice the Ancient Law, Custom and Manner of the Kingdom. As for Henry the VII. he did not openly disavow reigning in the Right of his Wife. The Act of Parliament, by which he was recognised King of England, was capable of this Interpretation, as the Lord Bac. observes in his Henry the VII. and so, by this Construction, no Injury was done to the Hereditary Right of the Crown. Besides, Elizabeth the Queen de jure, made no Claim, and consequently, did tacitly resign, which seemed to make him de jure, as well as de facto King. The Law (which you mention) in Edward the Confessor's Reign, you must know, good Sir! is no Law, unless you reckon the saying of a Pope to be so. For this (as I am inform'd) is no more. And if you once begin to obtrude the Dictates of his Holiness for Laws upon the Nation, upon my word, your Cause will suffer by it; and you must have a care, that you be not answered with a Praemunire from Westminster-hall. By the Clause in King Henry's Charter, you mean, perhaps, that in King John's quoted in the Pastoral Letter, out of the Original Articles; as we are told. However this is more to your purpose; and I shall therefore consider it. Now. 1. This was King John's own Grant; and therefore cannot be pleaded as the original Right of the People. 2. It was a Grant extorted by Force and Violence; and therefore transfers no legal, and regular Right. 3. It was the Grant of a King, whose Misery, or Pusillanimity, or both, made him formally resign his Crown into the hands of the Pope; and therefore, 'tis no wonder, that he should
subject himself to the Barons, and People of England; as the most likely way to shake off his Sovereign Master, by engaging his Subjects to stand by him in the recovery of his lost Rights and Reputation, It was the Popish Yoke, which then lay heavy upon his Shoulders, and sunk him thus low; And to argue, that what he did, in this forlorn Condition, ought to be a Law to all his Successors, is a Popish Conclusion, drawn from Popish Premises; and does not become those, who would be esteemed the great Advocates of the Protestant Religion. And indeed, all the Precedents which you, after others, make use of, to uphold your tottering Cause, are drawn from those times, wherein Popery was Predominant in England, as well as in other places; and therefore ought not to weigh with us now, who do not stand upon that bottom.

(N. 20.) The Oath mentioned, Eccles. viii. 2. was the Oath of Allegiance, and (if you will) of Supremacy too, which the People took to the King, by and with the approbation of God himself. This Oath we all have, or ought to have, taken; and we have called God to witness the truth of our Intentions, Endeavours and Resolutions to perform this Oath: and if we dare for any respect whatsoever, violate this Oath; if for fear of plundering and undoing, Death and Torment; Hope of keeping our Estates, or getting more; If for these or such like Motives, we shall presume to be false to this Oath, we have just Reason to fear the Judgments of God upon us, who will not hold him guiltless, who taketh his Name in vain. There's no limitation in these Oaths of Allegiance and Supremacy, no more than there is in the Protestation; and for us so to limit, distinguish and subtlelise the Sense of these Oaths, as to make them no further obligatory than they shall make for our present wordly advantage, is contrary to the simplicity of an Oath; is a scandal to our Religion; and (in plain terms) is neither better nor worse, than (as Bishop Sanderson expresses it) to play fast and loose with God
himself, at the same time when we call him to witness the sincerity, truth and singleness of our Intentions.

God punished the King of Jerusalem, for breaking the Covenant he had made with the King of Babylon, Ezek. xvii, from verse the 12. to the 21. but was the King of Babylon therefore absolv'd from his part of the Covenant, so far as it was not expresly conditional, or necessarily so, in its nature? You might here have observ'd, That this Oath is not only call'd the King of Babylon's Covenant, but that God himself also calls it, mine Oath; but then, you ought to make this serious Reflection, That an Oath taken to a lawful Sovereign is questionless no less the Oath of God, no less than this, which was taken to Nebuchadnezer the Conquering Tyrant. And if God held himself oblig'd to punish the breach of this Oath, will he hold them guiltless (think you) who can so easily dispense with the Oaths which they have taken to their rightful King, when no Conquest is pretended? In the Oath which the two Spies swore to Rhahab, there was a condition plainly mention'd. But if thou utter this business, then we will be quit, &c. Jos. 11.20. Would any one therefore but your self, from this particular, conclude in general—That the Non-Performance of an Oath on one side, makes the other become void? What reasoning is this?
