Pray Sir, shew us that you are a Man, at least, of some common Sense, though you be no great Clerk. Your Argument from the Father's ratifying or disannulling the vow of his Daughter; or the Husband's, that of his Wife; seems more proper to the business in hand; but yet, when 'tis nearly examin'd, we shall find it as lame and imperfect, as the rest. Daughters and Wives are immediately under the care of their respective Fathers and Husbands, and therefore by their Authority they might confirm or vacate the vows of their Wives and Daughters; but what is this to an Oath taken by the People to their Prince? Who shall dispense with this Oath? surely none but the Prince or God himself. If the Prince doth not, let any one shew me, that God, by his word, hath absolv'd me, and I will be his Proselyte as long as this Oath remains lawful in it self, and possible
to be perform'd, so long it certainly binds if any Oath can oblige the Conscience. But if Oaths are but Words,
—And Words are but Wind,
Too feeble Instruments to bind; then, I confess, they are in the right of it, who (to save themselves and their Fortunes) resolve to take any Oaths, and keep none. Then— Jura & Perjura, secretum prodere noli— is a commendable peice of Prudence; and they who walk by this Rule (or rather no Rule at all) are the only wise Men, whose example we ought to follow. But if this Wisdom descend not from above, but (like the gross Vapors of the Earth) arises from beneath; and is Earthly, Sensual, Devilish; then God grant I may never be amongst the number of these Wise Men, but rather one of those foolish and despised things, who chuse Affliction, rather than Sin; and to be miserable in this World, rather than run the fatal Risque of being so hereafter.

Our next Inquiry is, Whether Protection, be the only Ground and Foundation of Allegiance? You say it is. And your Reason is, because the Prince Swears to Govern and Protect the People according to Law, &c. So then, 'tis Swearing to Govern and Protect the People according to Law, that is the Foundation of Allegiance, and not barely his Protecting and Governing the People according to Law, if he doth not Swear to do so. And thus Allegiance at last, is resolv'd into the Coronation Oath. But what if the Prince is willing, when he is not able to Protect his People according to Law, as he has Sworn? What if another, stronger than he, shall come and dethrone him, and (taking the Government into his own hands) shall himself swear to Govern according to Law? Must I obey the former, or the later? My rightful Prince, who has Sworn, and is willing but not able to Protect me? Or the other, who has also Sworn, and is (we'll suppose) as willing, as he is able to Protect me? Not the former; for his Power is gone, and he
cannot Protect me, though he has Sworn that he will, and is desirous to keep his Oath. I must therefore, according to your Principles, obey the later; and thus at last the longest Sword carries it, and becomes the only sure Foundation of Allegiance; and consequently the King of France, as I said (at least if he shall Swear to Govern according to Law) ought, if he be the strongest, to be received by all those who make Protection the only Foundation of Allegiance; so unluckily do some Men form their Arguments (when they design to serve an Interest) as to oppose that very interest, which their Arms are at the same time employ'd to support and maintain.

N. 21.) I'm glad to find you so favourable as to grant, That 'tis not every little violation of the King's, by which the Subject is absolv'd from the Oath of Allegiance; but if the King endeavours to overthrow the Government, &c. They are not (you say) bound by this Oath, to stand still, and let him. But if the Sovereign Authority cannot lawfully be resisted by Force of Arms, they can only perswade, remonstrate, humbly beseech, and intreat him not to follow such evil Councils. And this you know, was done by the great Confessors of the Nation. This Oath, in your judgement, is not to be taken in the literal Sense; and you reckon up the grievous inconveniences, which would thence ensue. Now I confess, I have hitherto thought, That all Oaths are to be taken in the plain literal and Grammatical Sense, and no other; for this only is the Sense which cuts off all Aequivocations and mental Reservations whatsoever; whether Jesuitical, or Puritanical. I must needs tell you, that you do here advance the most pernicious and damnable Principle, both in respect of Religion and Civil Society, that ever any Man, since Symon Magus, pretended to countenance. If an Oath is not to be taken in the literal Sense, then what doth it signifie, Whether I swear to observe and teach the Articles and Canons of the Church of England, or those of the Council of Trent? Whether I undertake to make the Bible or the Alcoran the Rule of my Faith? To tell People that an Oath is not to
be taken in the Literal, but in any Sense whatsoever they shall put upon it, is quite contrary to the Nature and End of an Oath; which is, to cut off all ambiguity, and double dealing with one another. And this can never be, if the Words of an Oath must not be taken in their plain, common, obvious and Literal Sense. As for our Baptismal Vow (which you endeavour to debauch, as if it did Authorize your Principle of Resistance) I pray God, that we may all keep that better than hitherto we have done, and then we shall, I doubt not, be less Solicitous, how to find out evasions, whereby we may absolve our selves from the Oath of Allegiance.

Your Head is so full of Government, and King James's violation of it, that the frequent repetitions of these things, do serve you for Answers to every thing; and consequently, to nothing. Here follows a great deal to this purpose; which I shall pass over in silence, as I desire to do hereafter, as often as I shall meet with the same Crambe repetita.

The Fortune of War in Flanders (which you insist upon) comes not up to the present Case. For, our late Revolution, is not a Conquest; neither is it so received, the Title is grounded upon another bottom. First, that of the Peoples Election. The Scripture directs Obedience (you say) to the Powers in Being. You ought to have added, upon the pain of Damnation. Now put these two together, and what will hereafter become of them, who were lately so far from obeying the Power in being, i. e. King James, that they deserted, betray'd and oppos'd him, He was. 'tis evident the Power in Being, and whilst he was so, by your own Rule, the Word of God pronounces them disobedient Rebels and Traytors, who forsook and delivered him up into the hands of his Enemies.

Hitherto you have labour'd to prove, That if the King breaks his Coronation Oath, his Subjects are absolv'd from that of Allegiance. You do now give us a word or two, concerning the King's Obligation to observe the Coronation Oath, when his Subjects do not keep that of Allegiance. And to
what you say, let those return an Answer, who are concern'd. —If the People endeavour to destroy or kill the King, the Coronation Oath neither does nor can bind him to Protect them; but on the contrary, he commits a notorious Sin against the Law of Nature, if he does not defend himself, and destroy them; if there is a necessity for it, to preserve himself.

(N. 22.) My Assertion is, that the Public would suffer more by the Impunity of bad Subjects, than of evil Kings. You maintain the contrary. And the reason which you offer is, because Subjects are punishable for the least Misdemeanors, and the King not. But if it once be taken for granted, That Kings are punishable by their Subjects, the People must judge when 'tis fitting they should be corrected; and to save themselves from being punished for their own faults (whether great or small) they'l, you may be assured, be beforehand with the King, and judge his small Misdemeanors to be great Crimes; and will call him to an account for them, when they are strong enough to set a Guard upon him, and bring him before an High-Court of Justice in Westminister-Hall. Then the Motes in the King's Eye, shall (through their false Opticks) be magnifyed into Beams; and they (not beholding the Beams in their own Eyes) will be very much concern'd to clear the King's Eye-sight.

When the King ceases to Govern by Law, he doth not (as you say) cease to govern, but he ceases to govern as he ought to do; but this none (except some of Corah's Companions) will say, doth un-king him, and utterly destroy his Regal Capacity. And if this was the Case (supposing the worst) when the Prince of Orange Landed, the consequence is easie. Your Reply to the 18th and 19th Paragraphs I have already consider'd, to which you refer me, as if your chief strength lay therein. If it doth, I must tell you, that I am in no apprehe • sions of all the force you can bring against me.

(N. 23.) Here we are agree'd; and the Foundation of our agreement is—That none are obliged to do any thing that is sinful, though it be commanded by the greatest Potentate upon Earth.
But then I wish we were agreed in another point, which is, that we ought to suffer, rather than Rebel, when the Supream Power commands that which is sinful. These two things being granted, the matter might be easily accommodated betwixt us.

(N. 24.) I am for perswading Men to perform their Duty, both to God and their Country; but you will needs divide these two, and suppose Men Rebels either to the one or the other. And then you speak, as if (like one of the Jewish Zealots) you were appointed by God, to execute Vengeance upon the Rebellious. How can I be true to my King and Country, if I let Men Rebel against the Laws, by violating them every day? This is spoken like a Man of Authority, and carries with it such a dominant and decisive Air, as better becomes one of the King's Judges, than any private Man, as I suppose you to be. If you be otherwise, I beg your Pardon.

(N. 25.) But now comes the great Stumbling-block, Passive Obedience; which I find gives you such offence, that it puts you out of all patience, and makes you rave like a Man, who together with his Christianity, has also lost his Reason. Your Position is, that Passive Obedience is Popery Established by Law, and by consequence, slavery, whenever the Prince shall please. To which my Answer was—Passive Obedience is neither Popery nor Slavery Establish'd by Law, but the Doctrine of Jesus Christ, grievous to none but those, who desire to use their Liberty as a Cloak of maliciousness. This Answer (you say) is not direct. Let's compare it with yours. Passive Obedience (you tell us) is Popery, Establish'd by Law. Passive Obedience (I say) is neither Popery nor Slavery Establish'd by Law. Which directly opposes your Assertion, taking in also the second Part of it; and by consequence Slavery, whenever the Prince shall please. I add over and above—But the Doctrine of Jesus Christ is grievous to none, but those who desire to use their Liberty, as a Cloak of maliciousness. I shall now (if you please) give you my Sense, in this Affirmative Proposition; Passive Obedience, is Christianity Establish'd by the Gospel, and by consequence is so far from being Slavery, when
ever the Prince shall please, that they who always Act agreeably to this Principle, can never be made Slaves by the most Arbitrary Prince upon Earth. The Apostles and Primitive Christians, who govern'd themselves according to this Doctrine, were so far from being Slaves, that they were the most Free-men alive, at the same time when their Persecutors were under the Dominion of their impotent Lusts and Passions; the worst sort of Slavery to which a Rational Man can be condemn'd.

But you'l Answer, That the Slavery which you mean, is that of the outward Man— First, the Subjecting our Lives, Liberties and Estates to the Arbitrary Pleasure of the Prince. To this I reply, That this sort of Slavery, is falsely charged upon Passive Obedience; which is no more the cause of it, than righteousness is the cause of Sin, or Vertue of Vice, because sinful and vicious Men may make their advantages both of the one and of the other. Passive Obedience is not such a creeping thing as you imagine. It knows how and when to stand up in the Vindication of all goods Laws, and Laudible Customs of the Country, without running into Rebellion for God's sake; or making Christ to appear the Author of confusion and destruction amongst Mankind, instead of Justice and Order; as your words are. Passive Obedience sees, and obeys God in every thing; and is ready to vindicate all that's good and just, even with the loss of life and all that's dear to Men in this World; but yet, will never by Violence and Force of Arms, endeavour to right it self against its lawful Sovereign. Such a Subjection as it requires, is every where suppos'd in Scripture, and is agreeable to the Reason of Mankind, not blinded with Prejudice, or the Interest of this World.

By this Obedience, Christianity was at first propagated, and it must be still maintain'd. When all is done and said; after we have try'd all the ways of preserving our Liberties, &c. after we have kill'd and affrighted one another with Wars and Rumors of Wars; at the last, Passive Obedience rightly understood, will be found to be beyond all Stratagems and Strength; and Prayers and Tears (how much soever despised)
the strongest Arms of your Church. To cherish this Doctrine, is not (good Sir) to degenerate from Nature, unless it be corrupted Nature which you mean; out of which Mr. Hobs and his Disciples have taken their depraved Principles. This Doctrine neither tends to the destruction of Christianity, nor any Human Society. On the contrary, it elevates and improves Men's Reason; and of Wild and Savage Heathens makes them mild and gentle Christians, true Disciples and Followers of the Innocent, and Holy Jesus, the Prince of Peace.—To what a degree therefore of Folly and Madness, to give you your own words (but I hope better apply'd) are some Men arrived, who deride and damn a Doctrine, which is peculiar to Christianity; and absolutely necessary for the support of the truly Ancient, Catholick and Apostolick Religion; against all the Persecutions of wicked and unreasonable Men; of what denomination soever?

I could easily recriminate and charge Popery and Slavery too, upon some of our late Proceedings; though the cry was altogether against these two Companions. But 'tis well known, that (the People of England having such an irreconcilable hatred to these two Enemies of Religion and Liberty) the only way to introduce them, is loudly and bitterly to exclaim against, whilst at the same time, all Arts are used to Establish them, under some popular and specious Pretences. But I shall not here draw this Parallel at length; only give me leave to say, that if Odelschalchi himself, the late Pope, was consulted, and the measures of the Vatican were followed in the late Revolution; this is no very great sign, methinks, that the Interest of Popery is not at the bottom: And if the Dutch Scheme and Methods of Policy, must be the Standard and Platform of our Government (as 'tis very likely they must in most things, except the name of King) 'tis very probable, that, how much soever we may promise Liberty to our selves, we shall, at last, see our selves reduc'd to as great Slavery as the poor People are in Holland; where (if we will believe the learned Grotius, who had reason to know the State of that
Country) there remains nothing but the name of Liberty. Cum videam (says he in his Epistle 298. written to Ger. Vossius) apud vos, ubi tantum pro Libertate depensum est, vix quicquam ejus praeter nomen restare. Grot. Epist. fol. 108. But, to conclude this Section; This Doctrine of Passive Obedience ('tis true) as all that is good, may be abused. And I question not, but Men of Intrigue have endeavour'd to bring about their own bad Designs, by the means thereof. But, if the abuse of any thing is a sufficient Argument against it, the Sun it self, ought to be removed out of the Firmament; because Evil Men use the Light thereof, in the perpetration of the Works of Darkness.

N. 26.) What Q. Elizabeth did in reference to the French Protestants and the Hollanders, let the Statesmen answer for. I am no competent Judge in the case. I do not take upon me to dive into the Reasons of State, or determine concerning the Actions of Independent Princes, towards one another. If this great Patroness both of Law and Religion did deviate something from her usual measures in this Affair, it may serve to put us in mind, that the best of Governours and of Princes are but too apt sometimes to follow their Interest rather than their Duty. Her Answer to the French Embassador, in the Case of the Queen of Scots, was, I'm sure, of another Nature. Abdicandi principes exemplum, perniciosum est, & infrà inferos damnandum. The Example of abdicating Princes is indeed pernicious; and ought to be condemn'd to the Pit of Hell. Cambd. Eliz. Lat. fol. 223.

N. 27.) You have (you say) as honourary a respect for a King as any Man whatsoever, whilst he continues his Kingly Office (i. e. whilst he pleases you) but when he shall degenerate and break all his sacred Oaths; (i. e. when he doth not Rule according to your liking) then you have (i. e. you think you have) Reason to turn your Love into Contempt. Though all be true that you have said of King James, yet you have reviled the Lord's anointed. For who gave you Commission to tell him of Faults, and maliciously to publish such stuff to the World?
'Tis neither decent, nor dutiful for a Private Person to lay open the failures and miscarriages of his Prince; and take all occasions (as you do in every Paragraph, and almost in every line of this Pamphlet) to expose him as a Person not only unfit to govern, but to live. This intemperate Zeal of yours, what popular Cloak soever you shall throw over it, to me appears to be nothing else, but Reviling your King.

To your Question, what Right hath the King to the Throne, but from the People? I will answer, when you can shew me, that the People ever had any Right at all to make Kings. In the mean time to your Question I shall only oppose this. What Right have the People (especially of England) to Judge, Condemn and Depose one Prince, and set up another? What ever becomes of the Jure-Divino Doctrine (which we shall speak of afterwards) the successive Hereditary Monarchy of England, is establish'd by Law, and you'l grant, I hope, that 'tis Jure-Divino, to maintain the lawful Constitution of every Nation.

(N. 28.) That God did command or appoint his own People the Jews to be govern'd by Monarchs all along, (tho they were not always call'd Kings) I do find by the Scriptures; That, he ever revoked that Form of Government, I do not read. Yet, I will not, I tell you, maintain, that all other Governments are sinful. If you be resolv'd to prove this (as you say you will, p. 31.) pray do you undertake the Province; and shew us—That the Government by Kings is necessary, and that all others are sinful.

N. 29, 30.) I beg leave, Sir, to ask you where you have lived, that you never till now heard that a Paternal (i. e. A Fatherly Authority as you critically observe) is a Kingly Authority. Our Education, it seems, has been very different. For I scarce ever heard otherwise, but from those who would have all Kings to be so many Nimrods; not Fathers, but Robbers and Spoylers of their Country.

Why may it not be said, that Adam was a King, as to his Power and the Exercise of it, when besides the Dominion
given to him over the Fish of the Sea, the Fowls of the Air, &c. he had (as you grant) Power and Authority over his Children, to subdue them, if Rebellious in disobeying his Commands? What Power and Authority has any King greater than this? If he had Dominion over all Creatures, and Empire over all his numerous Family, you cannot reasonably deny, that (considering how long he lived, which was until about 620 Years of Noah's Flood, for the Deluge happened after the Creation about the Year, 1656. And Adam lived 930 Years; so by a moderate Computation we may allow him to be a Monarch over some Millions of People) that he was the first, and none of the meanest Monarchs of the World. As for the name of King, I will not contend with you about the Word, if you yield the thing it self.

The Twelve Sons of Jacob, after the Flood (you agree) were Chief Fathers, and Chief-Head Princes of their Families: and such (as you go on to argue for me, as well as I could wish) was Abraham who was called a Father (not King) of many Countries. All this confirms my Notion. For a Father of a Country is a King in my Sense of the Word. And consequently, the Patriarchs (being chief Fathers of Families and Countries where they lived) were, in effect so many Kings. And Abraham (being a Father of many Countries) was perhaps one of the most Potent Kings, at that time, in the World. Thus, during the time of the Patriarchs, there is no difference betwixt us, but about the name. And this Scripture-Notion of Kingly and Paternal Power being the same, Aristotle himself (though no great Friend to Monarchies) had learn'd; when (convinc'd either by the Reason of the Thing or the Authority of these Holy Writings) he tells us—That Regal Power belonged to the Father of the Family, Polit. Lib. 1. Cap. 8.

We now pass on to the time of the Judges. And they (you say) were not Monarchs, for the time being, but Rulers over the People. Now that Judges were Rulers of the People, for the time being, is very true; but it doth by no means follow,
that, therefore they were not Monarchs. For, 'tis evident that they were single Rulers, that is, so many Monarchs or Kings for time being. As for the Text which you quote upon this occasion, you might as well have referr'd us to any Text in the whole Bible, wherein the word (Rulers) is to be found. The words are—Then Peter, full of the Holy Ghost, said unto them, ye Rulers of the People, and Elders of Israel, &c. Do you fancy, these Rulers, unto whom St. Peter here address'd himself, to have been of the same Nature with those, who were made Judges of Israel, after Joshua's time? If you do, I pitty your Ignorance. 'Tis such a mistake as must needs spoil your Credit, with all your Readers, even those of the meanest Capacity; for whom you seem to write. After such an escape as this, for shame, never pretend to set up for an Expositor of Scripture, and throw out such foolish Challenges against those, who, I assure you, do better understand these Sacred Writings, and have more Veneration for them, than to abuse and pervert them so miserably as you have done here and in other Places.

But to go on with you; you allow that Melchisedeck and Moses, are said, in Scripture, to have been Kings, and that God also owned Cyrus for his anointed; but Melchisedeck was a Type of Christ; Moses a very Holy Man; Cyrus made a Decree to Build the House of God; and therefore these Persons (you say) were particularly honoured with these Titles. It may, with Reason, be concluded, that God gave him an Honour above other Prophets, by making him a King (say you of Moses.) Now, since you grant the Title of a King to be an Honour, I hope, in time, you may be reconcil'd unto the Office; and not derive all Kings from Nimrod, who seems to have been recorded rather as a Tyrant, than a King; and may be the first Example of a wicked Prince, not the first Monarch, we meet with in the Scriptures.

The Judges and Officers, which the Children of Israel were commanded to make, throughout their Tribes (in Number 12, as you learnedly observe, and lest we should not believe
you, cite two Texts for it, Gen. xlix. 28. Mat. xix. 28.) These Judges and Officers, were all, at the time of their first institution, under Moses; and you known the end of some of these Men of renown, who rose up in Rebellion against him, who, at that time, was King in Jeshurun. And in after times these Judges and Officers, were all under the Kings of Israel; as our Judges and Officers are under the Kings of England. They were a sort of Magistrates, as much different from those Judges, who, in times of eminent danger, were chosen for Israel's Deliverance; as the Pretors and other Officers, were from the Roman Dictators, who were made upon extraordinary occasions, and had the Power of the the Sword committed to them for the time being. And so the Judges of Israel had Kingly Power, whilst God pleased to continue them in their Office; and though they are sometimes said to have been chosen by the People, yet in truth, they were always raised up, and chosen before by God himself, as Gideon was. Judges iv. 12, 13, 14. And so, this makes nothing at all, against the Jure Divino Doctrine; which yet, together with that of Passive Obedience, you grant, did obtain during the time of the Children of Israel. p. 35.

This concession I cannot let pass without some Observations upon it; though I profess I am quite tired with examining your bold Assertions; when you bring neither Wit, nor Argument, nor Scripture (which you pretend to the most and know the least) to support them. Passive Obedience and Jure Divino, used (you say) to go together, during the time of the Children of Israel. Very good! Then the Old Testament is on our sides; and these Doctrines (you yield) were once approved by God himself, and delivered by him to his own peculiar People. If this be so, I desire you to shew, that the New Testament has altered the Case, and parted these two inseparable companions in the time of the Jewish-State; or else Passive Obedience and Jure Divino are still in force against you. Now, that the New Testament has made no alteration as to these things, I thus argue—Our Saviour strictly enjoyns
us to render unto Caesar, the things that are Caesar's. Passive Obedience and Jure Divino, did by your own Confession, belong unto Kings, during the time of the Children of Israel; i. e. till the time of Gospel.

Therefore I conclude, that the Rights of Caesar are from God; and that we ought, for the Lord's sake, passively to submit to his commands, when we cannot actively obey them. And thus we are both by the Law and the Gospel bound to govern our selves by these Doctrins. To say, That what was true concerning the King's of Israel, is not so, when apply'd to the Kings of the Nations, will do you no service. For Saul, and the Kings of Israel from his time, were (as the People desired) Kings, after the manner of the Nations.

But to insist no further upon this, I go on; and must demand satisfaction of you for your scurrilous and prophane expressions, which you bestow upon those Doctrins, which you acknowledge, went together, during the time of the Children of Israel. To quote the Scriptures, for them, is (you say) to wrest them; when the Scriptures especially the Old Testament, every where (you confess) doth suppose them. p. 10. They are Doctrins, which inevitably tend to the destruction of Christianity, and to all human Societies; p. 26. not fit for Savage Heathens, much less for rational Men. ib. Those who assert them, fit to be compared to Papists. ib. They are inhuman and damnable Principles. p. 37. Now, as for mine own part, I can easily pass by and forgive all these hard words, were I, or any particular Doctrins of mine own broaching only concern'd therein; but when these false accusations, and lew'd Epithites do reach the Scripture it self, and reflect upon God's own Institutions, during the time of the Children of Israel, (by your own account) what can you say for your self? What amends can you make for the injury you have done to the word of God, and for the scandal which you have given to Religion, and all good Men? What reparation can you make, but by acknowledging your Crime, and your serious repentance for it? And how can your Repentance be so, if your Retractation be not as
public, as the injury you have done to Religion; and the affront you have given to the Bible, and consequently to God himself, whose Word it is?

And as for the Doctrine of Non-resistance in particular, even the present Government it self is concern'd, to call you to an account, for what you have said about it. For, all it's true and real strength stands upon this bottom; and not upon the Principle of Fear, which is Tyrannical; and makes no consciencious impression upon Men's minds. If a Man does not obey for Conscience sake (as 'tis certain they do not who maintain the lawfulness of Rebellion in any Case) all the Cords of outward Pacts and Covenants will not hold him, when he Dreams that the Philistines are upon him, and he can deliver himself by Force, from the Power of his Enemies; as Dr. Tennison (in his Hobs's Creed) assures us. This is no more than the Loyalty of the Leviathan; says Mr. Pelling (Serm. Jan. 30. — 83. p. 43.) How necessary soever the Doctrine of Resistance, sometimes may be thought to be in bringing Men to the top of Empire and Greatness; that of Non-resistance will always be necessary to keep them in Possession. Accordingly I perceive, that this Doctrine is now likely to have it's Habeas Corpus; and be discharged from all those horrible Indictments, which by you and others of your Spirit, have been brought against it. For I find, by the Title of a Late Pamphlet, 'tis now the opinion, that this Doctrine is not concern'd in the Controversie betwixt the Williamites and the Jacobites; (as some learned Monk has taught them to distinguish.) So that you see, Sir, one of your Points is drop't, and given up (as I may suppose) by Authority. For, we have notice of this Phamphlet, in the Continuation of the Proceedings in Scotland, N. 58. Licensed and Entered according to Order. And as for the other thing which so much offends you, the Jure Divino Doctrine, it follows of course. For if it be in no Case lawful to rise in Arms against our Sovereign Prince, 'tis a sure sign that his Character is more than human; and consequently, that it is in truth, Divine. And thus your quarrel is groundless, even in the Judgment of those, whom you pretend to
serve; and the Doctrins which you so furiously damn, and which have provok'd you to make this unaccountable Challenge, are receiv'd into favour, or at least, begin to be look'd upon as innocent By-standers, not concern'd in the Controversie. And truly, the present Government, let me tell you, has as little Reason to suspect these Principles, as it has to encourage such a dubious and ill qualify'd Advocate for it, as you appear to be. All that you say, may be turn'd against one King as well as another; when your present Favourite shall displease you, or his good success shall fail him. And surely those useless Harangues ought to be despised by all sides, which do really serve none at all; and every Government, which bears the name of Kingly, ought to be jealous of one, who Advances such Opinions, as do equally strike at all Constitutions of that Denomination. I could easily present the Reader with a cast of your Loyal Sayings, which are Treasonous in the Eye of our Law, and have been often so adjudged when time shall serve, which side soever shall, at last prevail. So that, probably, you may live to make your own Recantation, and ask Pardon for your Republican Propositions and Assertions; instead of glorying in them, and undertaking to defend them, with your Learned Pen.

Thus, Sir, I have (according to your direction) examin'd this Paragraph; whether well or not, neither you nor I are to judge, but the honest and impartial Reader. This, I think, I may confidently say, that I have not wrested any Text of Scripture (as you charge me) neither have I, I hope, made any false assertion. This (as I remember) is the third time you have accus'd me for wresting the Scriptures. I do Challenge you to prove your Allegation, or else you must pass for a false Accuser of your Brethren, and you know, to whom that Character belongs.

As to your demand of proving Kings to be by the Command and Appointment of God Almighty; because you are importunate, I shall at present lay down these things, which I shall inlarge upon, as you shall give occasion. First, That de facto, God
hath commanded and appointed Kingly Government in the Scriptures, and no other that I know of. Secondly, That Kingly or Monarchical Government is absolutely the best in it self. Thirdly, That in England particularly, is an Hereditary Monarchy; and ought to devolve successively upon the next of the Royal Line. When you shall think fit to shew your skill, by opposing these Assertions, I shall, according to my small Abilities, endeavour to defend them. But let me Advise you to be more Methodical and Argumentative than hitherto you have been, or else I shall loose no more time upon you; but conclude, that your Talent lies rather in Dictating Political Aphorismes, than proving them by the Force and Evidence of Reason; and that, you'r resolv'd to hold fast your Conclusions, whatever shall become of the poor Premises, which ought to support them.

(N. 31.) You here repeated over again, what you said N. 20. and 21. and which I have in these places already considered. I am not at leasure to •• ke notice of your impertinent Objections, as often as you sha • l think fit to make them.

(N. 32.) As for the Law concerning an Usurper, or de facto King, 'tis the only appearance of Law, that you have on your side; which yet, if it be throughly scan'd, doth not in the least countenance, much less altogether excuse our late Proceedings. There are many things to be said concerning this Law, which the brevity of this discourse will not permit. I shall therefore breifly propose some things, which may be more fully insisted upon hereafter. As First, It cannot be reasonably supposed, that this Law doth Establish any such Principle, as they would draw from it, who produce it as an unanswerable Authority against all objections. The Principle, which our late States-men would draw from this Act, is, That, Possession of the Throne, without any other Right, is a sufficient Title? King Hen. 7. needed no such Principle, and therefore 'tis not probable, that the Parliament by which it was enacted, did intend to encourage any such Doctrine. Or, if it did, can it be thought that the ensuing Parliaments, would have left it
unrepeal'd all this time? In truth this Opinion—That Possession, without any other right, is a sufficient Title, is founded only upon Sr. Edward Cook's Authority, who first maintain'd. That a King de facto only, is Seigneur Le Roy within the purvein of the Statute of 25 Edw. 3. Now Sr. Edw. C. though he was a great Lawyer, yet has been, 'tis very well known, remarkably famous for corrupting the Law, as much as ever any one, of his Profession, ever did. Secondly, Supposing, that this 11. H. 7. did really intend to make Possession a sure Title, yet it cannot now be pleaded, because 'tis vertually repealed by the first of Queen Eliz. by which Statute we are oblig'd to Swear to be true to the Queen, her Heirs and lawful Successors, that is, those who have a Right to the Crown, by proximity of Blood. Thirdly, Supposing that this Statute is in Force at present, yet will not it be serviceable to those who desire to shelter themselves under its Protection. For 'tis provided in this Act—That no Person shall take benefit and advantage by this Act, which shall hereafter decline from his or their said Allegiance. This is the Proviso of this Statute, upon which a very learned Person (whose Treatise I have by me, and out of which I must confess, I have had most of these hints) thus argues. If Allegiance by this Act be due to a King de facto, then certainly (by the same Act) 'tis equally due to him, who is a King de facto and de jure too. Therefore those who decline from their Allegiance to a King de jure, are expressly bar'd from receiving any benefit by this Act. So that, now they must lye under the Lash of all those Antecedent Laws, which punish all Disloyal Practises against a rightful King, whether in, or out, of Possession. Thus doth this judicious Person reason upon this Act. And accordingly 'tis certain, that (notwithstanding this Act) by several Acts in the Reign of Edw. 4th, the Henrys were declared Ʋsurpers, and that during their Usurpations, the Ancestors of Edward the 4th were rightful Kings; and consequently all those, who were then alive, and did decline from their Allegiance to the House of York (the Right Line) to the House of Lancaster (the Kings de facto) might have been condemn'd
as Traytors, and precluded from having any benefit from this Statute. Notwithstanding therefore, any thing that you have said, or any other I have ever discours'd or read upon this Subject, the Oath of Allegiance to our King de jure still remains in full Force and Vertue, not only in point of Conscience, but of Law too.

(N. 33.) The Query is, Whether it he for the Safety of the People, to violate the Rights of Succession? To have given a direct Answer, you should have shewn, That the good which attends this violation, is greater than the evil which may be feared from it. But instead of this, you run immediately to the Divine Law; and fall upon asking questions, which I am no more bound to Answer, than you are Authorized to propose. You ask, whether the Salique Law in France, and the deposing the King of Portugal he according to this Law? And whether or no England for its security, may not exclude the next Heir to the Crown, or turn out he (him you mean) that shall be upon the Throne, who are (is you should have said) uncapable, or will not govern according to the Laws of the Land? I am no ways oblig'd to resolve these doubts, before it be decided, Whether to violate the Right of Succession (especially where it is Establish'd by Law) be for the Safety of the People? If this be once determin'd all your Queries will be easily solved; which otherwise cannot be Answered without Ambiguity. But because I love not to be uncivil, and because the Safety of the People, rightly understood, doth never clash with the Divine Law; what if I shall give you this general Answer, which both confirms my Opinion (i. e. that it is not for the Safety of the People to violate, &c.) and satisfies your Demands, in reference to the Divine Law?

'Tis most beneficial to the public, and most according to the Divine Law, that all Monarchies should be Hereditary and Successive; But yet this doth not hinder, but that some particular exceptions, might be lawfully made, by the Wisdom of a Nation, when the manner of the Succession was at
first agree'd upon. Such an exception is the Salique Law; but in England, we have no such exceptions agreed upon by King and People. As for your Instances in 18. and 19. Replies, I have already accounted for them. I confess I never have been so happy as to have seen the Fundamental Contract of the Nation, by which the People are Authorized to depose their King; upon pretence that he is uncapable, or will not govern according to Law; If you have it by you, and out of it can shew me that our Ancestors did (by vertue of this Charter) make King's and turn them out as they pleas'd; you will much oblige me by a sight of it. Till then, I must own, that I think it no essay (as you elegantly express it) upon our Reason, and that they were neither Fools nor Madmen, not to reserve to themselves such a Power. As for the business of Portugal, I am not so well vers'd in the Laws and Customs of that Nation, as to pronounce any thing about it.

(N. 24.) Here you insert the later part of your 29. Query, because, I was, it seems, so forgetful as not to take any notice of it in its proper place. I do assure you, Sir, this Omission was not because I thought it unanswerable, but rather because it deserved no Answer; and yet is treated as it deserves else where: For you have repeated it more than once. However, because 'tis your Herculean Argument, and the very Palladium of your Cause, I shall here again consider it. If Kings are by Divine Appointment, is it not rational to believe that God would have commanded all the World to have been govern'd by Kings, or at least the Christian World, and have given them a Law to govern by?

Thus you; to which I Answer—That Kings, whether they come to their Thrones by Inheritance, Donation, Conquest, or even Election it self, are by Divine appointment, I do not think; That God should therefore have appointed all the World to be govern'd by Kings, or at least, the Christian World, by an express Law, is not rational to believe, unless it be rational to prescribe to God Almighty, and tell him what he shall do. Yet 'tis
rational to believe, that this is the Government which he most approves; because we do not find that ever he erected any other Form of Civil Government but this; or, that we are commanded to pray for any other sort of Governors, but Kings and all in Authority under them.

Episcopacy is by Divine Appointment or Jure Divino. Yet where do we find that God hath, in express Terms, commanded all the World to be govern'd by Bishops? Yet the Constant and Universal Practice of the Church, hath recommended this Government as the best, and most agreeable to the Will of God. And thus the Authority and Universality of Kingly Government, do argue that it has been received by all Countries and Nations, as most agreeable to the Law of Nature, and consequently to the mind of him, who is the Author of Nature. Principio (says Justin in his History) rerum, gentium, nationumque imperium penes Reges erat. The Rule of all things, Countries and Nations, were in the hands of Kings, from the beginning.

By what follows it appears, that you are only for a King of your own making. The Reason is, that you make and unmake him again when you please. For, if the King for the time being, exceeds his bounds, then most certainly, the People who gave him his Authority, has Authority to take it away; so that your King is only a King durante populi beneplacito, and quamdiu bene gesserit. It concerns him therefore to look to himself, and beware of his pretended Friends, as much, if not more, than those, whom he may account his Enemies. For the People, who are his Judges, are very hard to please, and seldom continue long in one mind. They are partial and passionate Judges; and will soon Pronounce him Guilty and cast him off, as a Person not fit to govern, if he will not humour them in all their lawless and extravagant demands. And thus Kings for the time being (seeing they are only Tenants at Will to the People) are likely to have but a short, and probably, no very merry Reign of it.

What a perilous thing were it to commit to Subjects the judgement, which Prince is Wise and Godly, and his Government good, and which otherwise? As though the Foot must Judge of the Head; an Enterprize very heinous, and which must needs breed Rebellion. Thus our excellent Hom. against Rebellion (part. 1.)

(N. 35.) That the Roman Emperors did seldom Succeed by an Hereditary Right; and that the Primitive Christians were not bound to them by Oaths of Allegiance and Supremacy, you grant. Yet, the Commands (you say) of our Saviour and his Apostles for their Obedience—under pain of Damnation, were more binding, than any Oath those Princes could have required of them. I conclude therefore à Fortiori; That, if the Primitive Christians thought themselves so strictly oblig'd to Obedience, by the Commands of our Saviour and his Apostles, when they had taken no Oaths of Allegiance and Supremacy, and when the Empire was not Hereditary; That, if their case had been ours (who have taken these Oaths, and live under an Hereditary Monarchy) they would have thought themselves to have been doubly and tribly bound to have been subject to the higher Powers. They would doubtless, if possible, have been more Faithful and Loyal to the Emperor than they were: And if any one should have illegally usurp'd the Empire, they, I'm fully perswaded, would (as we do) have judged it a thing utterly out of their Power, to have absolv'd themselves from these Oaths; and consequently, that they could not in Conscience, have taken any new Oaths which should have been imposed, contrary to their former most solemn Obligations. In short, they would to the last have asserted (as they had sworn) the just Rights of the Emperors, his Heirs and lawful Successors.

(N. 36.) You ask, Why I undertake to prove the Doctrine of Passive-Obedience, and do not joyn Jure-Divino to it? Truly, Sir, for any opposition that you can make, I may undertake
to prove any thing. I have indeed undertaken to prove the Doctrine of Passive Obedience; and, if it will oblige you, I will also make good that of Jure-Divino, as I understand it; not in your Sense; as I told you before. For you think, that this Doctrine cannot be true, unless all those who are not under a Monarchical Government, be in a damnable State. This, I tell you once more, is no true consequence, and I do not undertake for it; how inhuman and damnable soever you may think my Principles to be.

You allow, That during the time of the Children of Israel (as I have observ'd before) when God did set up Kings, that Passive-Obedience and Jure-Divino went together; but now ('tis your Opinion) they have ceased. Why so, I beseech you? Were they only Typical and Figurative Observances? Were they some of those weak and beggarly Elements, from which the Gospel hath emancipated, and set us free? Shew this, or else they still remain Obligatory to you and me and all Christians; as well as formerly to the Jews (as I have remarked above.) If you say, that the Jewish Kings were of God's appointing, and ours are not; and that therefore these Doctrines cease to oblige, I utterly deny your Antecedent; and do maintain, That our Kings are as well of God's setting up as the Jewish were of Old. For by God's Appointment Kings succeeded one another, by an Hereditary Right; except when he pleas'd, by some particular Revelation, to Command otherwise. By me Kings Reign, is a Text applicable to the Kings of England, as it was to those of Israel; that is, they instruct us, that all lawful Kings do Reign, not only by Divine Permission (as you pervert these words) but Commission; as all good Expositors understand them. At the first, you must grant, that Kings were made by God himself; and where, and when, I desire to be inform'd, hath he assign'd this Power over to the People? Not surely, when they rebelled against Moses and against Aaron; no, nor when Saul had broken his Coronation-Oath with a Witness; and ceased to
govern according to the best Law, that ever any People lived under.

As for the Contrarieties which you desire me or any Man else to reconcile, I wish that I may never be put upon an harder task; for then, I shall never need to call any other Man to my Assistance. Is it a contrariety to say, that he who resists, (i. e. By force of Arms) doth not only resist the Ʋsurpations of Men, but the Ordinance of God, though the Person be a Claudius or Nero: And that Absolute and Ʋnconditionate Obedience is due only to God, and to the King no otherwise, than as he is his Vicegerent: Are these things inconsistent, with that averseness, which I profess to have from having my Throat cut either by French or Irish Dragoons? You, who advance the Principle of Self-preservation above all Laws Divine and Humane; will you not suffer me, to be so far influenc'd by it, as to have some Reluctances of Flesh and Blood, and to avoid Persecution (if I may honestly do it) when yet rather than resist the Ordinance of God, I'm willing meekly to submit to any Punishment? But when I said, I am and shall be as averse as you from having my Throat cut, &c. You thought, I'l warrant you, that my meaning was—I am and shall be as forward to handle my Weapon, and resist by force of Arms, as your self. You much mistake, if you understand me in this Sense. And so your supposed Contrariety vanishes into nothing. But I have said more than enough upon this occasion; having already, in the beginning of this Answer, clear'd my self from this Imputation; as also that of being a notorious Hypocrite as your extraordinary Sincerity is pleased kindly to salute me. I will not recriminate; yet let me Counsel you for the future, to be more modest in your personal Reflections; if you intend, that you and I shall have any further Discourse upon these Points.

(N. 37.) And now, Sir, as for my Conversation (which you do Hypothetically accuse) it has, I hope, been agreeable to my Sentiments; and my Prayer is, that it may ever so continue.
They that know me can, and many I question not, will (if there was occasion for it) testify, that I have always even in the worst of times, freely declar'd my self against all Rebellious and Schismatical Practices. And, I am so far from being asham'd of what I have done, that I shall, notwithstanding all discouragements, still endeavour, by the Grace of God to approve my self a Loyal Subject, and an Obedient Son of the Church of England; however she shall be distress'd, or wheresoever dispers'd. 'Tis my Religious Constancy to the Monarchy and Church of England, which moved me to bestow a few Remarks upon your Paper; which is so destructive both to the one and the other. And, tho now, Ruine and Destruction seem to threaten both; yet, I doubt not, if our Sins do not prevent (which God forbid) but that we, once more, shall see the time, when our Holy Mother shall appear from behind the Cloud, in her former Lustre, and Majestic Simplicity: When those her otherwise Pious and Learned Sons, who, I hope, have rather suspended, than quite abjur'd their Duty, shall return into her Bosom: when renouncing all Rebellion, Heresy and Schism, we shall all, as usually, go into the House of God as Friends; and with one Heart and one Mind glorify him, the Father of our Lord Jesus Christ.

(N. 38.) And now I have almost done with my Author; and should indeed here conclude; but that he would account me rude, or something worse, if I should make no return to his Challenge; which here he sends me and all other Men, who still persist in these inhuman and damnable Principles; that is, to all Passive-Obedience and Jure-Divino Men in England, nay in the whole World, as the direction is more civilly worded in his first Paper.

Really, Sir, you have acquitted your self with so little Honour in the management of your first Challange, that neither I, nor any one else, can expect to gain any Credit, by accepting your second. Yet that, if possible, you may
be brought to know your self, and your Hogan Mogan Courage may be a little humbled; I have, without any Seconds, ventur'd, you see, to enter once more with you, into the Lists; for, to what purpose should I (as you advise) consult with others, when I have such an easie Adversary to deal withal? Two (they say) are too many for Hercules himself; I'm sure one is an over-match for a Man of your Skill and Conduct. And Pardon me, Sir! if (as mean Opinion as I have of my self,) I am encouraged, by the advantage of my Cause, to ingage with such a Goliah in Controversy as your self.

Your bold Challenges and small Performances brings to my Mind the Italian Proverb; which I think may not be improperly apply'd to your self,
—un altro Orlando,
Non con fatti, ma parlando,
In Truth, you're just another Orlando;
Not in Deeds, but saying what you can do. You talk a La Cavaliere, and as if no body could stand before you; when your performance is so mean, that there's not a Passive-Obedience or Jure-Divino-Man in England, no nor I believe in the whole World, but will easily make his part good with you, and baffle your ill-guarded Propositions. I profess my self one of the meanest of them; yet appoint your place, and fit your Weapons; I am once more at your Service, to dispute the Truth of these Doctrines with you.

But, if you shall think fit to appear again, let me counsel you to take more care of your English, than to offend
against the common Rules of Grammar; to avoid Repetitions as much as may be (for I'm sensible that all that you and I have said, abating these Tautologies, may be comprised in a much less room;) to be more clear and distinct in your Reasonings, and more consistent with your self; not to accuse me for wresting the Scriptures, when your self do so very much abuse these Sacred Writings: Lastly, abstain (if I may obtain that favour of you) from fixing odious Names and Characters, upon Things or Persons; unless you shall be very well assured, that they deserve them. Let your Arguments be as hard as Rocks; but let modesty and ingenuity direct and accompany your Words.

And thus you have both my Answer and Advice. If the one doth not satisfy you; it's your own concern more than mine, to follow the other. But if you shall reject both the one and the other; I have only lost so much time upon you, though I hope, others, may reap some little benefit from what hath been said. I profess, had I found any thing in this Answer of yours, to have convinc'd me that these Principles are erroneous and damnable, I should have here publickly recanted them; for I desire willingly to Sacrifice my Reputation to the Interest of Truth, and our Common Salvation. But being fully confirm'd in these Doctrines (and more by the weakness of your Objections) I resolve, by the Grace of God, to be true to the Convictions of mine own Mind, and never by any mean, sneaking and unlawful Compliances, to renounce those Principles, which are founded upon Reason, Law and Scripture; as they have been defended not only with the Tongues and Pens; but the Blood and Lives of the wisest Men, and best Christians in all Ages of the Church. And particularly, the Church of England, has always, ever since the dawning of the Reformation, defended these Doctrines with all Christian
Meekness, Simplicity and Courage. And 'tis a surprising Change to find such a sudden and extraordinary Alteration in so many of her Sons; and those otherwise, both her Ornament and Glory. This turns her Joy into Sadness, and her rejoycing into Tears. Her Clergy for their Learning and Piety, and Constancy in the Faith, used to be the wonder of the VVorld. And how fearful, how sollicitously concern'd is she, (lest for Reasons of another nature, and which she is unwilling to mention) it be now said—Stupor mundi Clerus Brittannus?

div.head: Post-script TO THE AUTHOR.
div.p: I Have thought fit not to give your Bookseller the trouble of these Papers. And one Reason is, because as (I remember) it was about four Months before I heard any thing of that short Answer, which (according to your Direction) I before sent to Mr. Randal Taylor: So that I had almost given over all expectations of seeing any thing against it. But at last, when you had finished the great Work, you were resolv'd, That the World should know it by giving notice of your Performance, in the Public Gazette. And truely, had you not done so, it's probable, that I (as well as others) had still been ignorant, That any Return was made.

As soon as I had thus found, that you had undertaken me, I expected that your Atcheivement had been answerable to the pompous Proclamation of it; And therefore I presently sent for your Book. But how fearful, may you imagin, was I to open it, and see my self led in Triumph after your Victorious Propositions! However, I ventur'd to read it from one end to the other; And after I had done, found my self as safe and sound, as I was before, notwithstanding all the terrible Shocks, of your High and Mighty Assertions. This encourag'd me to set Pen to Paper, and defend what I had Written: To defend one's self is natural, but the obligation to defend the truth is indispensible. And truely, the Cause is so good, and your Objections so very insignificant, That no Commendation is due to me, if these things, which I offer to the ingenuous and honest Reader, shall be thought a full and sufficient Reply to all your pittiful Cavils, false Reasonings, ungrammatical Periods, and (what is worse than all these) malicious Reflections upon a Company of Men, whose Learning and Piety, will perpetuate their Names, as long as useful Knowledge and true Christianity shall have any esteem amongst Men.

Let me farther acquaint you, that if you shall ask, why this Answer comes out so late; it is for a Reason, which you know very well, and I need not stand
to explain. Had the Press been as open for Writings of this kind, as it is for those of a contrary nature; My Papers had been Printed, as they were finished, within a very little time, after I received your Answer. However at last you see, they have made a shift to get into the World. And as for the Principles, which they maintain, they are free Denizons, and naturalized Subjects of England; And how much soever they may be blamed, yet if they may be heard (as the Judges of the Areopagus did their Advocates) in the dark, they are not afraid to appear before the Bar of the strictest Justice. That is, if Partialities of Affection and Passion be laid aside, they will I perswade my self not only be acquitted, but encourag'd—But as for Men of your interests and prejudices, they expects nothing less than to be put out of the Protection of the Laws; and (as Strangers and Foreigners) sent back to the poor, distressed and suffering State of Christianity, from which (you confess) they came, and to which (as you will have it) they only belong. In the mean time, how hardly soever they may be treated by you and your Brethren, they assure themselves of a kind Reception from all, whose Prayers and Endeavours are sincerely directed to the good and prosperity of the State and Church of England; and more especially (when by such Judges as your self,
they shall be condemn'd as pernicious and damnable Principles) they doubt not but that, at least, they shall have the benefit of their Clrgy; for whose Reputation and Honour they are chiefly concern'd.
